GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 51.01 ESTABLISHMENT OF UTILITY.
   There is hereby established a garbage collection and disposal system in the
city which shall be operated by the city as a governmental function in its
corporate capacity, or by contract as the Council may from time to time by
resolution determine.
(1986 Code, § 10.02.010) (Ord. 517, passed 3-17-1942)
§ 51.02 UNDER DIRECTION AND CONTROL OF BOARD OF HEALTH.
   Until otherwise directed by resolution, the collection and disposal of
garbage in the city shall be under the direction and control of the Board of
Health Committee, and the Committee shall cause the garbage in the city to be
collected and disposed, either as a governmental function by the city, or by
contract as the Council may from time to time by resolution determine or
direct.
(1986 Code, § 10.02.020) (Ord. 517, passed 3-17-1942)
§ 51.03 PROVISIONS FOR AN ANNUAL APPROPRIATION AND A TAX LEVY.
   The Council of the city, in its annual appropriation and levy ordinances,
shall annually appropriate the amount sufficient to cover the cost of
collection and disposal of garbage in the city, and annually levy a tax to
raise money to cover the cost, not in excess, however, of the amount authorized
by law. The tax when so collected shall be in addition to the amount authorized
to be levied for general purposes.
(1986 Code, § 10.02.030) (Ord. 517, passed 3-17-1942)
FEES AND CHARGES
§ 51.15 FEE IMPOSED ON EACH RESIDENTIAL HOUSEHOLD.
   (A)   Effective March 1, 2012, there shall be imposed, on each residential
household in the city, a charge which will be a per month charge for the
collection and removal of garbage, refuse and ashes within the city, which will
be sufficient to pay each residential household’s share of the total per month
contract price payable by the city to the independent garbage collection
contractor designated by the city for garbage collection within its city
limits. Establishment of this rate and any adjustment in the rate pursuant to
this section shall be by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the City
Council.
   (B)   EffectiveApril 1, 2023, there shall be imposed on each residential
household in the city a charge of $10 per month in addition to the rate imposed
for garbage collection. This additional charge will be for:
      (1)   A yard waste pick-up service, and an “over-flow garbage” pick-up
service which shall be provided by the city for each residential household in
the city; and
      (2)   An administrative fee to cover handling customer service issues
related to yard waste pick-up service, and for the “over-flow garbage” pick-up
service.
   (C)    For purposes of this section, the term OVER-FLOW GARBAGE means those
items that are refused to be picked up by the city's independent garbage
collection contractor, EXCEPT for the following items, which will not be picked
up by the city: construction material, tires, paint cans, TVs, VCRs, DVD/Blu
Rays, electronic entertainment playing devices, computers, computer tablets,
paint cans, any items deemed hazardous waste by either the United States EPA or
the Illinois EPA, and containers holding flammable liquids.
(1986 Code, § 10.04.010) (Ord. 1529, passed - -2000; Ord. 1668, passed 9-25-
2007; Ord. 10-0126-02, passed 1-26-2010; Ord. 12-0410-35, passed 4-10-2012;
Ord. 19-0924-185, passed 9-24-2019; Ord. 23-0314-325, passed 3-14-2023)
§ 51.16 PAYMENT OF BILLS; NONPAYMENT OF BILLS.
   The charges for the garbage collection service shall be payable on the first
day of each month succeeding the month during which the services are furnished
or were available. If any charge is not paid by the fifteenth day of the month
in which it is due, a penalty of 10% of the amount due shall be added thereto
and collected therewith. The water supply, electric supply and gas supply may
be shut off from any premises for which the garbage collection bill remains
unpaid for a period of 20 days after the bill is rendered and mailed. This
shutoff of water, electricity and gas shall be in accordance with §§
50.01 through
50.03.
(1986 Code, § 10.04.020) (Ord. 1529, passed - -2000; Ord. 22-0412-282, passed
4-12-2022)
§ 51.17 DEFINITION OF RESIDENTIAL HOUSEHOLD.
   For the purposes of this subchapter, each living quarters for a separate
family shall constitute a separate RESIDENTIAL HOUSEHOLD.
(1986 Code, § 10.04.030) (Ord. 956, passed 3-7-1972)
§ 51.18 RATE ADJUSTMENTS.
   (A)   The chief executive entity of the city is hereby authorized and
directed to execute on behalf of the City Council any decrease or increase in
garbage collection rates which result in the entering of the city into a
contractual agreement with the garbage collection entity. Furthermore, any
changes of service rates as a result of any existing garbage collecting
contract shall be reflected by an equal rate increase to be passed on to city
residential households in an amount equal to the increase or decrease in the
contractor’s rate for services rendered.
   (B)   The chief executive entity shall direct the City Collector to
implement the garbage collection decrease or increase in rates beginning on the
next service cycle whenever possible, but in any event no later than the
billing cycle immediately following the month in which the service rate change
was increased or decreased by the contractual agreement. The chief executive
entity shall direct the City Collector to add the charge of $10 per month for
the yard waste pick-up service and the over-flow garbage pick-up service to
each residential household customer's monthly utility service bill.
(1986 Code, § 10.04.040) (Ord. 1529, passed - -2000; Ord. 19-00924-185, passed
9-24-2019; Ord. 23-0725-335, passed 7-25-2023)
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
§ 51.30 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ASHES. Residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings.
   GARBAGE. Waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and
consumption of food; waste from the handling, storage and sale of produce.
   REFUSE. Combustible trash, including, but not limited to, paper, cartons,
boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood furniture,
bedding; non-combustible trash, including, but not limited to, metals, tin
cans, metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete,
glass, crockery, other mineral wastes; street rubbish, including, but not
limited to, street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catchbasin dirt, contents of litter
receptacles; provided, refuse shall not include earth and wastes from building
operations, nor shall it include solid waste resulting from industrial
processes in manufacturing operations such as food-processing waste, boiler-
house cinders, lumber, scraps and shavings.
   YARD WASTE. Grass, weeds, yard trimmings, leaves, tree branches, vines,
plant material, tree stumps and bushes, which shall be placed b the customer
near the road or alley.
(1986 Code, § 5.14.010) (Ord. 19-0924-185, passed 9-24-2019)
§ 51.31 UNCOVERED GARBAGE.
   It shall be unlawful to place or permit to remain anywhere in the city any
garbage or other materials subject to decay other than leaves or grass,
excepting in a tightly covered metal container.
(1986 Code, § 5.14.020) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.32 WIND-BLOWN REFUSE.
   It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes or
trash of a material that it can be blown away by the wind anywhere in the city,
excepting in a covered container.
(1986 Code, § 5.14.030) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.33 DEPOSITS ON STREETS.
   It shall be unlawful to deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any
garbage, refuse or ashes on any public street or alley in the city; provided
that this section shall not be construed to prohibit placing garbage, refuse or
ashes in a container complying with the provisions of this code preparatory to
having this material collected and disposed of in the manner provided in this
code.
(1986 Code, § 5.14.040) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.34 CONSENT OF OWNER.
   It shall be unlawful to dump or place any garbage, refuse or ashes on any
premises in the city without the consent of the owner of the premises.
(1986 Code, § 5.14.050) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.35 DISPOSAL.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to dispose of any garbage, refuse or ashes
anywhere in the city excepting in an incinerator or disposal device, properly
constructed and operated or in a lawfully established garbage or refuse dump.
   (B)   This material not so properly disposed of shall be placed in
containers for collection by the city as prescribed in this code.
(1986 Code, § 5.14.060) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.36 PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE OF VIOLATION.
   The fact that garbage, refuse or ashes remain on any occupant’s premises in
the city in violation of this subchapter shall be prima facie evidence that the
occupant of the premises is responsible for the violation of this subchapter
occurring.
(1986 Code, § 5.14.080)
COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICES
§ 51.45 DEFINITION.
   For the purposes of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COVERED ELECTRONIC DEVICE or CED. Any computer, computer monitor,
television, printer, electronic keyboard, facsimile machine, video cassette
recorder, portable digital music player that has memory capacity and is battery
powered, digital video disc player, video game console, electronic mouse,
scanner, digital converter box, cable receiver, satellite receiver, digital
video disc recorder, or small scale server sold at retail and taken out of
service at a residence.
(Ord. 14-0923-79, passed 9-23-2014)
§ 51.46 DISPOSAL IN GARBAGE PROHIBITED.
   It shall be illegal for any person, firm, corporation, limited liability
company, or other entity to dispose of any CED within the city by depositing a
CED in any container from which the city garbage service will collect contents,
or by leaving a CED at the curb for pickup by the city garbage service.
(Ord. 14-0923-79, passed 9-23-2014) Penalty, see § 51.99
§ 51.47 DISPOSAL AT CAREER DEVELOPMENT CENTER PROHIBITED.
   It shall be illegal for any firm, person, corporation, limited liability
company, or any other entity to deposit a television or computer monitor in the
Career Development Center drop box or leave a television or computer monitor on
the Career Development Center property in the general location of the Career
Development Center drop box for donated personal property which is to be
reconditioned and sold at the New 2 You retail store operated by the Career
Development Center.
(Ord. 14-0923-79, passed 9-23-2014) Penalty, see § 51.99
§ 51.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter
shall be fined not less than $75 nor more than $750 for each offense; and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 20-0512-211, passed 5-12-2020)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 52.001 ESTABLISHED.
   It is ordained by the City Council that the existing gas system shall be
owned and operated by the city.
(1986 Code, § 9.02.010) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.002 TURNING ON.
   No gas from the city gas supply shall be turned on for service into any
premises by any person but the Superintendent of the Gas Department or an
employee authorized by him or her to perform this service.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.010) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.003 APPLICATION FOR NATURAL GAS SERVICE.
   The service of the gas utility shall be deemed to be furnished to both the
occupant and the owner of the premises receiving the services, and shall be
deemed an obligation of both the occupant and the owner to any premises.
Application for new natural gas service shall be made in writing to the City
Collector, and shall contain an agreement by the applicants to abide by and
accept all of the provisions of this chapter as conditions governing the use of
the city gas supply by applicants. The form of application for natural gas
service shall be as approved by the City Council. A fee of $150 shall be paid
at the time of application.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.020) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.004 RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL CUSTOMERS; SERVICE NON-REFUNDABLE FEE.
   Prior to receiving city gas service, all residential and commercial gas
utility customers shall be required to make a service non-refundable fee
payment with the City Collector as required by §§
36.075 through
36.077 of the municipal code.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.030) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992; Ord. 20-1124-239, passed
11-24-2020)
§ 52.005 INSTALLATIONS, GAS APPLIANCES AND ACCESSORIES.
   (A)   Gas service may be refused for premises in which the installation does
not comply with the ordinances of this city.
   (B)   All service connections shall comply with the requirements of the
Federal and State Pipeline Safety Acts.
   (C)   All gas appliances and accessories connected to the city gas system
shall comply with the requirements of the current NFPA 54 edition.
   (D)   All piping shall be as required under §
52.071.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.040) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.006 SERVICE CONNECTIONS; FEES.
   (A)   All connections to the city gas utility system shall be made by the
city. The city shall charge for connecting three-fourths inch or smaller taps
to existing main the actual cost to the city for contractual labor and
materials regardless of the length of the service line required.
   (B)   Service lines and other fittings larger than those required for a
standard connection shall be paid for the applicant at the actual cost to the
city upon completion.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.050) (Ord. 1378, passed - -1992; Ord. 08-0812-05, passed 8-
12-2008)
§ 52.007 DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE DUE TO NONPAYMENT OR VIOLATION OF THIS
CHAPTER; RECONNECTION FEE.
   Bills for gas service shall be rendered monthly and shall be delinquent in
accordance with §
52.051. If any bill shall remain delinquent, then gas service shall be
discontinued and shall not be re-established except upon payment of all
delinquent bills, together with a delinquent reconnection charge (D.R.C.) of
$50.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.060) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992; Ord. 20-1124-238, passed
11-24-2020)
§ 52.008 RECONNECTION CHARGES.
   (A)   A reconnection charge shall be paid to the city to restore natural gas
service at any time that it has been disconnected or discontinued by voluntary
request of the customer.
   (B)   Disconnect and reconnection charges shall be paid to the city at any
time natural gas service has been disconnected or discontinued. A charge of $25
shall be paid as a disconnect charge (D.C.) and an additional $50 shall be paid
as the reconnection charge (R.C.). This shall apply to all customers under all
circumstances who voluntarily disconnect and reconnect to the city gas utility
services.
   (C)   Additionally, if service has been terminated for nonpayment of a
delinquent bill, the delinquent reconnection charge (D.R.C.) as stated in §
52.007 must also be paid.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.070) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992; Ord. 20-1124-238, passed
11-24-2020)
§ 52.009 UNLAWFUL INTERFERENCE OF DOGS AND OTHER ANIMALS WITH THE GAS SYSTEM
BELONGING TO THE CITY.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or customer to tie or
leash any dog or other animal to any meter, regulator, service pipe or other
gas service equipment or facilities of the city gas system.
   (B)   It is further unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or customer
(collectively hereinafter referred to as the “customer”) to harbor a dog or
other animal in an enclosed or fenced area within which lies the city gas meter
or gas service connections of the city with its customers where the dog or
other animal shall interfere with the city gas system personnel reading meters
or maintaining gas facilities. The customer may be allowed to maintain an
enclosed or fenced area for their dog or animal, if the customer, at the
customer’s own cost, installs or has installed a utility meter that may be read
remotely. However, all authorized agents or employees of the city shall still
have free access to the customer’s premises at all reasonable hours for the
purpose of performing maintenance work, examining, inspecting, repairing,
replacing, exchanging, testing or removing meters or other equipment.
   (C)   The city shall have the right to terminate gas service to any person,
firm or corporation or customer who shall violate any provision of this
section.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.075) (Ord. 1407, passed - -1993; Ord. 22-0823-295, passed 8-
23-2022) Penalty, see §
52.999
Cross-reference:
   Interference with utility meters by dogs or other animals, see §§
50.15 through
50.17
§ 52.010 TESTING OF FUEL GAS PIPING.
   The fuel gas piping beyond the city meter must be tested by the customer’s
installer. The testing shall be done in accordance with the latest edition of
NFPA 54. The city may refuse to connect or reconnect any customer piping not so
tested and documented.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.080) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.011 APPLIANCES TO BE VENTED.
   All gas appliances except gas ranges and clothes dryers must be vented in
accordance with the latest revision of NFPA 54.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.100) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.012 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   All gas meters and gas fixtures, connections and appurtenances on private
property connected with the gas system of the city shall be open to the
inspection of the proper officers and employees of the city at all reasonable
hours or when necessary.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.130) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.013 TAMPERING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the city to tamper
with, alter or injure any part of the city gas system or any meter.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.140) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992) Penalty, see §
52.999
§ 52.014 CITY NOT LIABLE FOR INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE OR SUPPLY.
   (A)   The city shall have the right to shut off the supply of gas whenever
it is necessary to make repairs, improvements, enforce rules or for any
operating reason. In all cases, where possible, a reasonable notice of the
circumstances will be given to the customers, but in an emergency or discovery
of an unsafe condition the gas may be shut off without notice. Necessary repair
or work will be made by the city as rapidly as may be practical. The city shall
not be held responsible or liable because of any shut off or discontinuance of
service for any direct or resultant damages to any person, company or customer.
   (B)   In the event of a discontinuance of gas service, the city will make
every attempt to safeguard the customer and service shall not be renewed until
the city authorities have purged the lines and put into service all automatic
controls and pilots. In no case shall the customer turn on his or her own
service. The purging of lines, relighting pilots and checking automatic
controls will be done by the city. Where the nature of the customer’s
operations are such that an interruption of service might create a hazard or
large economic loss, the customer shall provide facilities for standby service
at his or her discretion.
   (C)   Whenever mains, pipes, service connections or other facilities of the
gas system are taken up, shut off or interfered with by reasons of any street
improvements, the city will endeavor to maintain service so far as is
reasonably possible, but will not be directly or indirectly liable for any
interruption, poor pressure or inconvenience of any kind either to the
customers adjacent or to other customers affected thereby. Direct damages to
property due to the operations shall be either repaired or replaced by the city
without cost to the customer.
   (D)   The city expressly stipulates with all customers and other persons who
may be affected by the discontinuance of service that it will neither ensure
nor be responsible or liable in any manner for any loss or damages, direct or
indirect, by any reason, of any fire or any other cause, and all gas service
furnished shall also be conditional upon acts of God, inevitable accidents,
fire, strikes, riots or any other cause.
   (E)   Any customer having a facility, operation, process or activity which
cannot under any or all conditions tolerate temporary interruption of gas
service shall provide an alternate source of on-site fuel or heat for
utilization during the interruption. The responsibility for this alternate
rests fully with the customer.
(1986 Code, § 9.04.150) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992; Ord. 1407, passed - -1993)
SERVICE PIPES
§ 52.025 INSTALLATION.
   All service pipes from the gas mains to the gas meter of premises served
shall be installed by the city.
(1986 Code, § 9.06.010) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.026 SPECIFICATIONS.
   Services shall be installed to conform to requirements of the Department of
Transportation Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration PHMSA
office of Pipeline Safety Section 49 CFR Part 191, Part 192.
(1986 Code, § 9.06.020) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.027 REPAIRS.
   All repairs on service pipes from gas mains to the gas meter shall be made
by the city.
(1986 Code, § 9.06.030) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.028 EXCAVATIONS.
   Excavations for installing service pipes or repairing the same shall be made
in compliance with requirements for notification through the statewide one-call
system shall be followed.
(1986 Code, § 9.06.040) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.029 SERVICE LINES NO LONGER IN USE.
   (A)   Whenever service lines for gas are permanently no longer in use, the
City Gas Department shall make a cut-off from the pipes at a point indicated by
the Superintendent of the Gas Department.
   (B)   The maximum period of time to declare non-use shall be 18 months
unless shortened by state or federal requirements.
(1986 Code, § 9.06.050) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
METERS; RATES; RECEIPTS
§ 52.040 METERS REQUIRED.
   All premises using the city gas supply must be equipped with an adequate gas
meter furnished by the city.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.010) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.041 INSTALLATION OF METERS.
   Meters shall be installed in location that will be easily accessible and
designated by the Superintendent of the Gas Department.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.020) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.042 READING METERS.
   The city shall read every gas meter used in the city at those times as are
necessary that the bills may be sent out at the proper time.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.030) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.043 RATES AND CHARGES.
   The basic rates and charges for the use of gas service of the City Gas
Department of the city shall be established by the City Council by ordinance
and adjusted from time to time by resolution of the city as provided in this
chapter.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.050) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.044 RATE SCHEDULE.
   (A)   There shall be, and there are established, monthly rates and charges
for the sale of natural gas and for the use and service supplied by the natural
gas distribution systems of the city based upon the amount of gas consumed as
shown by the gas meters.
   (B)   (1)   The rates and charges are as follows:
 
General Service Rate
Facility charge                 $10 per month, per meter
Base rate for all gas delivered $1.0104 per Mcf
 
      (2)   Commencing April 1, 2023, for Year 1 (and on the first day of April
for each subsequent year) the monthly meter charges for gas meters (for each
meter) and for each subsequent corresponding Year, shall be as follows:
 
Year Date Commencing Gas Meter Charge
1    April 1, 2023   $17.00
2    April 1, 2024   $18.50
3    April 1, 2025   $20.00
4    April 1, 2026   $21.50
5    April 1, 2027   $23.00
 
   (C)   The gas charge is to be added to the above rates.
   (D)   The residential and commercial rates charged by the city for the sale
of natural gas shall be increased by 5% effective September 1, 2010. The 5%
increase in natural gas rates shall be calculated by using the natural gas
rates in force on August 1, 2010 as required by this section of the municipal
code. The adjusted rate is represented as follows:
 
Residential Gas for August 2010
$8.7146 x 5% = $0.44 per Mcf
 
   (E)   The residential and commercial rates charged by the city for the sale
of natural gas shall be increased by 5% effective March 1, 2011.
   (F)   The utility rates charged by the city for the sale of natural gas to
residential and commercial customers and the costs and expenses which are
incurred by the city shall be evaluated in December, 2011, and in December in
each and every year thereafter in order for the City Council to make a decision
about any utility rate increases which may be advisable.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.051) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992; Ord. 10-0126-02, passed 1-
26-2010; Ord. 10-0810-07, passed 8-10-2010; Ord. 20-0714-219, passed 7-14-2020;
Ord. 20-0728-221, passed 7-28-2020; Ord. 22-0726-291, passed 7-26-2022; Ord.
23-0228-324, passed 2-28-2023)
§ 52.045 GAS CHARGE.
   All natural gas charges per unit of volume shall include on each billing a
gas charge determined by a projection of the annual cost of gas to be
purchased, divided by the projected volume to be billed to the customers based
upon the last July through June year. The result shall be known as the gas
charge and shall be applied to each unit of gas delivered.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.052) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.046 OPERATING EXPENSE ADJUSTMENT.
   Any changes in operating costs (not including cost of gas or tax) shall be
passed uniformly and directly to all bills rendered after the determination has
been made by the City Council. The determination shall be made using the
current fiscal audit report. Changes in operating expenses shall be limited to
the following:
   (A)   Demonstrable changes identified in the fiscal reports of the city;
   (B)   Changes in wages, salaries, payroll or payroll expenses applicable
after they have been put into effect; and
   (C)   Direct and permanently continuing costs over which the city has no
control.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.053) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.047 TAXES.
   The state gas revenue tax and all other federal, state or local taxes, now
in force or which may be enacted, based upon the operations of, or revenue of,
the gas utility, shall be uniformly and directly applied to all consumer bills
for gas service in addition to other rates and charges provided in this chapter
for gas service.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.055) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.048 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply for
the purpose of gas billing by the city.
   Mcf. One thousand cubic feet of natural gas.
   THERM. Volumetrically as 100 cubic feet of natural gas.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.058) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.049 CITY COUNCIL MAY IMPOSE SPECIAL RATES.
   The City Council reserves the right to impose rates and charges by special
contract or agreement where gas is furnished under circumstances which make the
general service rates in effect inadequate, inappropriate or unworkable, and to
fix and impose special charges if interruptible service is given.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.060) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.050 COLLECTION DUTY ASSIGNED.
   It shall be the duty of the officials of the city diligently to collect the
charges imposed by this subchapter and to employ the proper means for the
collection thereof.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.070) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.051 PAYMENT OF BILLS; NONPAYMENT OF BILLS.
   (A)   The charges for gas service shall be payable on the first day of each
month, succeeding the month during which the service was furnished or was
available. If any charge is not paid by the fifteenth day of the month in which
it is due, a penalty of 10% of the amount due shall be added thereto and
collected therewith. The gas supply may be shut off from any premises for which
the gas bill remains unpaid for a period of 20 days after the bill is rendered
and mailed. When shut off, gas shall not be turned on except as provided in
52.008.
   (B)   The City Collector shall terminate gas utility service for nonpayment
of gas utility service pursuant to the notice and procedure as provided in §§
50.01 through
50.03.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.080) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992; Ord. 1433, passed - -1995;
Ord. 22-0412-282, passed 4-12-2022)
§ 52.052 MONEYS RECEIVED; DISPOSITION; ACCOUNTS; AUDITING.
   It shall be the duty of the City Collector to set up and maintain a proper
system of accounts and records separate from all other accounts and records,
showing the amount of revenues received from the gas utility. All moneys shall
be paid by the City Collector to the City Treasurer, who shall also keep an
account of moneys received from the gas utility and the application of revenues
and all financial transactions in connection therewith, and who shall deposit
the moneys in an enterprise fund account. The accounts shall annually be
audited properly by an independent public accountant as provided by the State
Municipal Accounting Act.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.090) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.053 LIEN.
   (A)   Charges for gas shall be lien upon the premises as provided by
statute. Whenever a bill for gas service remains unpaid 60 days after it has
been rendered, the City Collector may file with the Recorder of the county a
statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of
the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city
claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for gas served
subsequent to the period covered by the bill.
   (B)   If the consumer of gas whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the
premises, and the City Collector has notice of this, then notice shall be
mailed to the owner of the premises, if his or her address is known to the City
Collector, whenever the bills remain unpaid for a period of 60 days after it
has been rendered.
   (C)   The failure of the City Collector to record the lien claim or to mail
the notice, or the failure of the owner to receive the notice, shall not affect
the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid gas bills as mentioned in the
following section.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.100) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.054 FORECLOSURE OF LIEN.
   (A)   Property subject to a lien for unpaid gas charges shall be sold for
nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay
the charges, after deducting costs, as in the case of the foreclosure of
statutory liens. Foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the
city.
   (B)   The City Attorney is authorized and directed to institute proceedings,
in the name of the city, in any court having jurisdiction over these matters,
against any property for which gas bill has remained unpaid 60 days after it
has been rendered.
(1986 Code, § 9.08.110) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
Editor’s note:
   See McQuillin Mun. Corp. (3rd Ed.) 18.18 note 44, 35.37 through 35.38,
53.103 note 57.
GENERAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF SERVICE
§ 52.065 SPECIFICATIONS FOR MAIN AND SERVICE CONNECTIONS.
   The city does adopt the requirements of the Federal and State Pipeline
Safety Acts as its specification base. Gas service connections made to the
mains of the system of the city shall comply with requirements and regulations
set forth within the Pipeline Safety Acts and related Pipeline Safety
Standards.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.010) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.066 ALL SERVICE METERED.
   (A)   No free gas service shall be furnished to any person, firm,
organization or corporation, public or private, and all rates and charges shall
be nondiscriminatory, provided that the Council reserves the right to impose
special rates and charges where particular circumstances render the regular
rates inadequate or unjust. If the city would elect to supply itself with gas
for any purpose, regular rates therefor shall be charged against the city and
payment made from the funds thereof to the Gas Fund.
   (B)   All gas service shall be metered with a meter of adequate size to
measure the amount of gas consumed. Meters shall be of standard design and may
be of the diaphragm, rotary or turbine type properly used at the discretion of
the city’s Utilities Superintendent. The measurement pressure base shall be
seven inches water column. The temperature base shall be 60°F.
   (C)   Estimated meter readings shall not be used, excepting in the case of
meter failure or proven inaccuracy, and then only in accordance with this
chapter.
   (D)   Monthly accounting for all metered gas compared to gas purchases shall
be done by the Utility Clerk and reported in writing to the Utilities
Superintendent.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.020) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992; Ord. 1407, passed - -1993)
§ 52.067 METERS AND THE LIKE TO BE OPEN FOR INSPECTION.
   (A)   All meters shall be so placed and installed as to render the same
accessible at the time for the purpose of reading and repairing. All meters
shall be set outside of the buildings. Indoor installations are prohibited.
   (B)   All meters, regulators, fittings, fixtures and appurtenances connected
to the system and located on private property shall be open for inspection by
the proper officers or employees of the city. Any part found to be defective or
not in compliance with the provisions of this section shall be immediately
repaired or corrected. Service may be discontinued without notice at any time
when conditions of the privately owned facilities create danger or hazard or
are found not in compliance with other sections in this chapter.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.021) (Ord. 1407, passed - -1993)
§ 52.068 METER READING CONCLUSIVE.
   (A)   All gas customers shall be liable for the gas consumption as shown by
the meter. Waste, leakage or other causes not the fault of the city shall be
included under the liability. The meter reading shall be conclusive provided
that when a meter is found to have a positive average error (i.e., is fast) in
excess of 2% in tests made at the request of the customer, the city shall
refund to the customer an amount equal to the excess charged for the gas
incorrectly metered, for a period equal to one-half of the time elapsed since
the last previous test, but not to exceed six months. No part of a minimum of
facility charge will be refunded.
   (B)   When a meter is found to have a negative average error, (i.e., is
slow) in excess of 2% in tests made at the request of the customer, the city
may make a charge to the customer for the gas incorrectly metered for a period
equal to one-half of the time elapsed since the last previous test, but not to
exceed six months.
   (C)   If a meter is found not to register or partially register for any
period, the city shall estimate the charge for the gas used by averaging the
amounts registered over similar periods, preceding or subsequent thereto, or
over corresponding periods in previous years, all of which shall recognize
weather conditions and degree day deficiencies. This action shall be taken only
in cases and substantial importance where the city is not at fault for allowing
the incorrect meter to be in service.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.030) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.069 TEST OF METERS.
   (A)   Any consumer may request the city to make a test of the accuracy of
the meter then in use on his or her premises. These tests will be made by the
city. The consumer shall be required to deposit with the city the sum of $25
for a meter having a capacity of 415 cfh or less. Larger meters shall be tested
at actual total cost of the work.
   (B)   In the event a meter is found by testing to register incorrectly at
20% full capacity, by more than 2% fast or slow as stated in §
52.068, then another meter shall be substituted and the test deposit shall be
refunded. Past gas bills shall be adjusted by refund or credit of the
percentage of the amount of the gas bills for a period of not more than six
months previous to the test as prescribed in this chapter.
   (C)   In the event that the meter is found to be within the limits and
registered correctly, the consumer shall forfeit the test deposit and the funds
shall be deposited in the gas operating funds of the city.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.031) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.070 SEPARATE METERS FOR EACH DISTINCT BUILDING.
   No person, firm or corporation shall connect any gas service line or
transmit gas applied by the natural gas system of the city into more than one
distinct building from one meter. A garage or similar outbuilding shall be
considered a distinct building. Each dwelling unit in apartment buildings or
duplex dwellings shall be serviced by individual meters. The City Council shall
have the right to establish special services or service connections as may be
necessary or desired for large users or for the convenience of the city.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.040) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992; Ord. 1407, passed - -1993)
§ 52.071 PRIVATE LINES; GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (A)   No additional connections shall be made with any private line or
customer-owned line. Private service lines or customer-owned extensions of
service are prohibited.
   (B)   The city shall have the right and option to demand changes, removal or
replacement of any pipe, fixture or apparatus which is considered to be faulty,
inadequate or hazardous; provided, however, that this provision shall not
obligate the city in any way or manner. The cost of the above work shall be
fully borne by the property owner. The city shall have the right to refuse or
to discontinue gas service without notice to a customer if the city finds any
installed apparatus or appliances which would be detrimental to the efficient
operation of the existing facilities under the latest revision of NFPA 54.
   (C)   All persons, firms, corporations and customers are strictly forbidden
to attach any electrical ground wire to any fixture or piping which is or may
be connected to any gas service pipe, meter or main belonging to the city. The
city will hold the owner of the premises responsible and liable for any damage
to its property or injury to the employees of the city caused by the ground
wire. Any and all customers, persons, firms or corporations shall remove any
existing ground wires immediately; and if the ground wires are not removed
after a 24-hour written notice, the city, through its officials, may enter the
property and remove the ground wires and the customer shall pay all costs.
   (D)   All questions and complaints shall be made in writing to the Gas
Department of the city for the proper investigation. The Department shall make
a report to be filed with the City Clerk and reported by the Clerk to the City
Council at the next regular meeting. All employees of the city are strictly
forbidden to demand or accept any tips, gratuity or other personal compensation
for any service whatsoever rendered during working hours.
   (E)   Any customer-owned lines which are required to be operated and
maintained by the city shall be subject to a monthly charge covering operation
and maintenance. The charge shall be an additional monthly amount equal to the
facility charge in effect at the time of billing.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.050) (Ord. 1407, passed - -1993) Penalty, see §
52.999
§ 52.072 REGULATIONS RELATIVE TO CUSTOMER’S PIPING, FACILITIES AND NECESSARY
VENTING.
   (A)   The responsibility of the city for maintenance and safety of natural
gas piping terminates at the outside residential wall in accordance with state
law.
   (B)   (1)   All house or mobile home piping shall be of rigid construction.
The pipe from the outlet of the meter shall be of black iron pipe of not less
than one inch inside diameter and shall enter the outside vertical house wall
or mobile home skirt. The pipe shall be secured or anchored by means of
suitable metal strap or clamp at a point not more than 18 inches from the meter
outlet and shall be fastened to the wall at intervals sufficient to make the
piping rigid throughout. All piping from the meter shall be securely fastened
so that the pipe will not turn when fittings are installed at the meter. The
final tie-in of the gas line to the meter shall be made by the city.
      (2)   Gas will not be turned on to any customer manifold that has not
been first air tested for leakage at ten psig or more by the applicant, or his
or her agent, and subsequently checked by the city. Testing must be done as a
completed system. No partial or temporary service is permitted. Customer
connections between the meter and the outside residential wall are prohibited
excepting for individual lines to serve gas grills or gas lights. All tests
must be held for observation by a city gas employee.
   (C)   The city does herewith adopt as its rules and regulations the safety
practices set forth by the National Fire Protection Association, in the latest
revision of the National Fuel Gas Code, NFPA 54, as though those provisions
were fully repeated and set forth herein so far as they are not inconsistent
with this chapter. In the event of conflict, the more restrictive language
shall apply. NFPA 54 is the National Fuel Gas Code. Any person, firm or
corporation installing fuel gas piping or appliances within the gas service
area of the city shall avail themselves of the Code prior to the undertaking of
any installation and shall follow it.
   (D)   No surface may be constructed or placed over a gas service line or
main which may produce a seal to a building wall or foundation or which may
obstruct ready access for repair or replacement.
   (E)   All buried natural gas piping facilities owned or served by the city
and distribution appurtenances shall conform to the latest revision of NFPA 54
and the Minimum Federal Pipeline Safety Standards, 49 C.F.R. pt. 192 as though
fully set forth herein. The minimum standards shall apply equally to private
buried facilities and distribution appurtenances. No natural gas piping may be
placed or remain beneath any building or sealed surface except in a specified
vented casing.
   (F)   No meter, regulator or any part of a city-owned meter setting may be
painted or otherwise coated by a customer without written approval of the Gas
Superintendent on a case-by-case basis. Special coatings are required to
prevent shorting of insulators.
   (G)   The city shall not approve customer piping, which as used herein means
piping beyond the outlet of the meter. The city may refuse connection or
discontinue service upon discovering any conditions which may be in violation
of this section or which may create any type of safety hazard, including
venting.
   (H)   (1)   Heating plants and water heaters shall be connected to gas
piping with rigid pipe, excepting where an AGA-listed flexible connector is
approved by the manufacturer as part of its installation design.
      (2)   Sweat fittings shall not be used anywhere in the gas piping.
   (I)   (1)   All gas conversion burners to be installed shall be AGA-listed
and approved. All designed heating plants shall be AGA-listed and approved and
the manufacturer’s recommendations for the installation shall be followed.
      (2)   No conversion burner shall be installed in any old or ineffective
furnace or a boiler which is in poor repair. Test for leakage shall be
conducted by the installer in an approved manner before placing a conversion
burner in a warm-air heating plant.
   (J)   No alteration, repair, adjustment, customer relighting, any appliance
work or piping work shall be done by city forces beyond the outlet of the meter
except to the extent that it may be required for purposes of safety only. This
prohibition shall apply to L.P. conversions.
   (K)   (1)   No unvented gas appliances excepting kitchen ranges, clothes
dryers and refrigerators may be installed or operated within the city.
      (2)   Safety shut-off devices to protect either supply gas or venting
failure shall be installed and subsequently tested for proper operation by the
installer. Written documentation of the test may be requested. These devices
shall be used when approved for or furnished with new heating equipment.
   (L)   Decorative or supplementary appliances shall be properly vented in
accordance with the NFPA 54. These include but are not limited to gas logs and
gas log lighters. At any time those units are installed in wood burning
fireplaces, special action must be taken for permanent modification of the flue
damper. Positive assurance must be provided that the damper cannot be fully
closed. A permanent hole must be cut or a positive stop attached even if the
unit has a safety pilot. The size of this opening shall be in accordance with
the table in NFPA 54 titled Free Opening Area of Chimney Damper for Venting
Flue Gases from Unlisted Decorative Appliances for Installation in Vented
Fireplaces. All other provisions for safety must be observed.
   (M)   The city shall be notified of any changes or alterations, remodeling
or reconstruction affecting gas piping in any building, house or grounds. This
shall be done using a new application for gas service or by amending an
existing application.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.051) (Ord. 1407, passed - -1993)
§ 52.073 CITY-OWNED EQUIPMENT DAMAGED.
   (A)   Whenever a meter, regulator or other equipment of a service connection
which has been installed by the city is found to have been damaged for any
cause whatsoever, these damages shall become the liability of the customer, who
shall pay the city the actual cost of removal, repairing and/or replacing of
the damaged equipment where damage was not caused by the city.
   (B)   In the event the damage has caused inaccurate metering, then the gas
bills shall be corrected in the manner previously provided for in this chapter.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.060) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.074 TAMPERING WITH PARTS OF GAS SYSTEM BELONGING TO CITY.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or customer to break
the seal of any meter or in any manner to make any alterations, changes or
repairs on the same or to open any mains, laterals, service pipe, stop cocks,
valves or any part thereof or otherwise tamper with or attempt to do any work
on either or any of them without authority from the city or its properly
authorized agent.
   (B)   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section or
who shall willfully or maliciously injure or damage any property connected with
the gas system of the city shall be subject to the penalty hereinafter
prescribed in §
52.999.
   (C)   Tampering shall include any type of confinement, enclosure, covering
over, surface sealing or changing of the environment relative to any parts of
the gas system or equipment of the city.
   (D)   Tampering shall become the liability of the customer, who shall pay
the city the actual cost of removal, repairing and/or replacing equipment or
material.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.070) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992) Penalty, see §
52.999
§ 52.075 RESALE OF GAS PROHIBITED.
   No gas shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the city
supply to any premises other than that for which application has been made and
gas installed.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.080) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
§ 52.076 EXTENSION POLICY; MAINS ONLY.
   (A)   (1)   Extension of mains and service outside of the city limits shall
be subject to approval of the Council and shall also be subject to all of the
rules and regulations and provisions as provided in this chapter or as may be
amended.
      (2)   All mains, lines and equipment shall immediately become the
property of the city.
   (B)   Where main installation is desired when funds for extensions are not
available and/or when the distance is in excess of 100 feet per customer noted
above, the extension can be made if the applicant will deposit with the city
the estimated cost of making the extension, less 100 feet when funds are
available, or the entire amount when funds are not available. The amounts so
deposited shall be refunded to the customer or customers at the rate of $0.80
per Mcf annually, until the total deposit has been refunded, or until eight
annual payments have been made, whichever event occurs first. The deposit shall
be interest-free. In the event that the amount deposited is greater or less
than the actual cost of the extension, the excess or deficiency shall be
corrected prior to giving service.
   (C)   The above applies to mains. See §
52.006 for service lines.
(1986 Code, § 9.10.090) (Ord. 1374, passed - -1992)
TRANSPORTATION OF END-USER CUSTOMER-OWNED GAS
§ 52.090 AVAILABILITY.
   (A)   Transportation under the rates specified in this chapter is available
to any applicable large commercial or industrial end-user customer:
      (1)   Having a proven natural gas requirement of more than 50,000 Mcf per
meter annually;
      (2)   Who has executed a written contract for deliveries hereunder at
specifically identified points of metering; and
      (3)   Who has arranged for the delivery of end-user customer-owned gas to
the Trunkline Gas Company system for the purpose of service under the contract.
   (B)   The rate is not available to any customer for transportation of
intrastate gas.
   (C)   The rate is available only on the basis of separate and distinct
meters.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.010) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.091 RATES AND CHARGES GENERALLY.
   Rates and charges payable monthly under this rate shall be as follows in §§
52.092 through
52.094.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.020) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.092 T-COG BASE MONTHLY CHARGE.
   The T-COG base monthly charge shall be $50 per meter each month during the
term or extension of the contract.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.021) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.093 INTERSTATE TRANSPORTATION CHARGES.
   All costs of any nature or type for or related to interstate transportation
in advance of the city’s point of receipt shall be paid by the end-user
customer.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.022) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.094 RATE FOR ALL GAS DELIVERED UNDER THIS RATE.
   The rate for all gas delivered shall be the amount per Mcf computed as the
net of the total rate chargeable under the applicable customer companion
classification rate less the applicable Trunkline SG-1 raw rate. The charges
for gas delivered shall include, but not be limited to, the ordinance companion
classification rate which may include facility charge, interruptible natural
gas rate, net rate, base rate, operating expense adjustment, gas charge and/or
any other applicable charges or credits as the City Council shall provide by
ordinance from time to time. Taxes or surcharges will apply as stated in §
52.097.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.023) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.095 INSTALLATION CHARGES.
   (A)   The customer shall pay or reimburse the city prior to the initiation
of service under this chapter for additional recording charts, instruments,
meters or other facilities required for the city to:
      (1)   Take end-user customer-owned gas into its system; and
      (2)   Record daily quantities of gas delivered to the end-user customer
hereunder at each meter so designated.
   (B)   If the city assesses other costs such as legal, engineering and
administrative expenses in connection with the delivery to the end-user
customer, these shall also be paid in advance.
   (C)   Amounts shall be determined by the city, billed to and paid by the
end-user customer prior to making any deliveries.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.030) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.096 LATE PAYMENT CHARGES.
   A charge for late payment shall be determined under the same provisions
applicable under city ordinance at the time of occurrence.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.040) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.097 REIMBURSEMENT FOR TAXES OR SURCHARGES.
   In addition to all other charges, the end-user customer shall reimburse the
city for any current or retroactive taxes or surcharges which the city may be
required to pay or be obligated to collect from the end-user customer in
respect of service hereunder. The city will bill the end-user customer monthly
or retroactively for any taxes. They shall include but not be limited to the
State Gas Revenue Tax and the Gas Research Institute (GRI) surcharge.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.050) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.098 ORDER OF DELIVERIES OF GAS.
   (A)   For billing purposes, gas taken by an end-user customer in any billing
period at the point of metering for this rate shall be deemed to be taken in
the following order:
      (1)   The quantity of end-user customer-owned gas delivered to the city’s
system in the current billing period;
      (2)   Any excess or “balance” quantity of end-user customer-owned gas
previously delivered to the city’s system but not taken by the end-user
customer during the billing period immediately preceding the current billing
period; and
      (3)   The quantity of gas delivered under the companion classification.
   (B)   Any excess or balance quantity not taken by the end-user customer in
the first subsequent billing period shall be forfeited to the city without
recourse and at no cost to the city.
   (C)   No balance shall be carried for more than 30 days following the close
of a month.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.060) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.099 NATURE OF DELIVERIES.
   Deliveries of gas under this rate are subject to full interruption. The city
shall be the sole judge of the necessity for interruption. The city will
endeavor to give end-user customers advance notice whenever an interruption is
required, and the customer shall interrupt his or her use of the end-user
customer-owned gas for the time and to the extent requested by the city. The
city shall not be liable for any loss of production or for any damages
whatsoever by reason of interruption or lack of advance notice. The city will
endeavor to deliver gas under the companion rate classification to the extent
of the then current entitlement of the end-user customer.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.070) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.100 MEASUREMENT OF GAS DELIVERED BY THE CITY.
   The gas delivered by the city under this chapter shall be measured in
accordance with the then current tariff of the Trunkline Gas Company. It will
include Btu values, pressure and temperature compensation, and chart recording
of volumes delivered on a daily basis through each end-user meter.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.080) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.101 GENERALLY.
   The terms and conditions of service set forth in §§
52.102 through
52.107 are in addition to the current city ordinance.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.100) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.102 CONDITION OF SERVICE.
   Service will be provided hereunder whenever and to the extent that end-user
customer-owned gas has been delivered for the end-user customer by the
Trunkline system in accordance with the contract between the end-user customer
and the city under this chapter.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.101) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.103 INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE.
   In the event of an interruption or curtailment of deliveries of end-user
customer-owned gas supply to the city, the city will attempt to make up any
deficiency in the supply to the extent of end-user customer entitlement. This
make-up service will be made available to the end-user customer under the
companion classification, to the same extent it would be available to the end-
user customer absent service under this rate, excepting in the event of
transportation of end-user customer-owned gas being the direct cause of
curtailment or reduction in gas entitlements from the city’s sole pipeline
supplier, Trunkline. Should historical purchase volumes under the companion
classification become the basis for Trunkline entitlements, then the end-user
customer will be provided the make-up service only to the extent of the volume
to which he or she is entitled. Loss of entitlements shall be the risk of the
end-user customer.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.102) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.104 DELIVERY OF GAS AT CUSTOMER’S EXPENSE.
   The delivery of end-user customer-owned gas by the end-user customer to the
city’s distribution system shall be fully at the end-user customer’s expense in
accordance with the contract entered into between the city and the end-user
customer.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.103) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.105 REFUSAL OF CITY TO ACCEPT DELIVERY.
   The city will not be obligated to accept delivery of any end-user customer-
owned gas if the acceptance is in any way detrimental to or at the subsidy of
other customers of the city. Refusal to accept delivery shall be at the sole
discretion of the city.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.104) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.106 TWO OR MORE METERS.
   The summation of the consumptions registered by two or more meters at the
points of end-user customer metering under this rate shall not be permitted
except as a matter of convenience to the city, as determined solely by the
city.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.105) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.107 FAILURE TO COMPLY.
   If the end-user customer, his or her agents, sellers, brokers, marketers,
shippers, transporters, suppliers or producers shall fail to comply with or
perform any of the conditions or obligations on the end-user customer’s part,
to be complied with or performed under the contract entered into between him or
her and the city hereunder, and if after the failure the city shall deliver at
the end-user customer’s local premises, addressed to him or her a written
notice of its intention to terminate service hereunder on account of the
failure, then the city shall have the right to terminate service at the
expiration of ten days after the giving of the notice, unless within those ten
days the end-user customer shall fully make good the failure. The termination
of service for any cause shall not release the end-user customer from the
obligation to make payment of any amount or amounts due or to become due in
accordance with the terms of his or her contract with the city hereunder or
under other conditions provided by city ordinance.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.106) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.108 SERVICE SUBJECT TO FUTURE REGULATIONS.
   Service is subject to any current or future ordinances, rules or regulations
of the city pertaining to natural gas service and not in direct conflict with
this rate or the contract between the city and the end-user customer.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.110) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
CONTRACT WITH END-USER CUSTOMER
§ 52.120 GENERALLY.
   The following §§
52.121 through
52.126 pertain to contracts with end-user customers.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.090) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.121 TERM.
   The contract entered into between the city and an end-user customer
hereunder shall continue for a mutually agreed initial term of not to exceed
two years from the effective date thereof, and extension terms not to exceed a
year-to-year term thereafter, subject to the right of either party to terminate
the same at the end of the initial term or of any extension term thereof by
written notice to the other given not less than 30 days prior to the date of
the intended termination. No third party shall have any rights under this
contract.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.091) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.122 MEASUREMENT.
   The contract between the city and the end-user customer shall provide for
the measurement of end-user customer-owned gas delivered to the city only
through the Fairfield-Trunkline M&R City Gate north of Sims, Illinois, the
point of receipt for the city, with quality meeting Trunkline’s specifications.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.092) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.123 FLOW RATES AND PRESSURE.
   The flow rate(s) of delivery of gas transported for any end-user customer
hereunder and the pressure at which the gas is to be delivered shall be agreed
upon by the city and the end-user customer and specified in the contract
between them or if not an end-user customer at current service conditions for
flow and pressure.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.093) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.124 MAXIMUM DAILY DELIVERY QUANTITIES.
   The contract between the city and the end-user customer shall specify the
maximum daily delivery quantities of end-user customer-owned gas. Trunkline
will provide the daily delivery data to the city for all end-user customer-
owned gas delivered to the city’s distribution system. Their determination
shall be binding upon the end-user customer. Delivery statements for end-user
account must be delivered to the city by the end-user customer by the tenth of
each subsequent month.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.094) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.125 ESTIMATES OF MONTHLY VOLUMES.
   The end-user customer must also provide the city with estimates of monthly
volumes to be transported. These estimates must be made available before
September 1 of each year or before deliveries begin.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.095) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
§ 52.126 THIRD-PARTY CONTRACTS TO BE PROVIDED TO CITY.
   The end-user customer will furnish the city with copies of all third-party
contracts relating to service hereunder, including all amendments thereof in
effect from time to time. Prior to the sixteenth of each month, the end-user
customer will notify the city in writing of the volumes of gas in decatherms to
be transported on a daily basis in the subsequent month. This will be converted
to or expressed as average daily flow. The end-user customer must request and
receive approval of the city two working days in advance of any mid-month
changes. They must be confirmed in writing immediately.
(1986 Code, § 9.15.096) (Ord. 1316, passed - -1988)
PROTECTION OF NATURAL GAS FACILITIES DURING AND FOLLOWING CONSTRUCTION
EXCAVATION
§ 52.140 CONSTRUCTION PLAN REQUIREMENT.
   All plans for construction work within the city limits which provide for any
excavation of the construction work site must include the general location of
all natural gas service lines and mains which cross the construction site or
are located within ten feet of the outer limits of the proposed construction
excavation. The excavation shall include, but not be limited to, trenching. All
excavation shall be done according to J.U.L.I.E. rules and regulations
(Illinois Underground Utility Facilities Damage Prevention Act, ILCS Ch. 220,
Act, 50 §§ 1 through 14).
(1986 Code, § 9.20.010) (Ord. 1332, passed - -1988)
§ 52.141 CITY OBSERVATION AT EXCAVATION SITE.
   A qualified employee of the city’s gas utility may be present at the site of
any excavation occurring within ten feet of any gas service line or other gas
facility.
(1986 Code, § 9.20.060) (Ord. 1332, passed - -1988)
§ 52.999 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter
shall be fined not less than $75 nor more than $750 for each offense; and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 20-0512-211, passed 5-12-2020)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 53.001 ESTABLISHED.
   It is ordained by the City Council that the existing electric system now
owned and operated by the city be included in a public utility and shall be
operated hereafter as a public utility.
(1986 Code, § 8.02.010)
§ 53.002 APPLICATION FOR SERVICE.
   Electric energy shall only be rendered after application for service from
the city electric distribution system from a prospective user shall be made to
the City Collector, who shall in turn refer the application to the
Superintendent of the Electric Distribution Department. The application shall
contain an agreement that applicant shall abide by and accept all of the
provisions of this chapter as conditions governing the use of the city electric
supply. Service shall then only be energized after inspection by the City
Superintendent. No fee shall be charged except as hereinafter provided. No
service shall be rendered unless proper metering has been installed.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.010)
§ 53.003 RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL CUSTOMERS; SERVICE NON-REFUNDABLE FEE.
   Prior to receiving city electric service, all residential and commercial
electric utility customers shall be required to make an electric service non-
refundable fee with the City Collector as provided in §§
36.075 through
36.077.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.020) (Ord. 1331, passed - -1988; Ord. 20-1124-239, passed
11-24-2020)
§ 53.004 WIRING, ELECTRICAL INSTALLATION AND EQUIPMENT SERVICE.
   Wiring, electrical installation and equipment service must be in accordance
with applicable electric codes and the rules of the city electric utility. The
utility reserves the right to refuse service to customers not in compliance
with this provision.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.030) (Ord. 937, passed 5-18-1971; Ord. 1251, passed - -1984)
§ 53.005 SERVICE CONNECTION; FEE.
   No charge shall be made for residential overhead electric service
connections, meters or installations. For underground or abnormal service
connections, the customer shall pay based upon the latest rate provided by the
bill provider.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.040) (Ord. 937, passed 5-18-1971; Ord. 1251, passed - -1984;
Ord. 22-0125-276, passed 1-25-2022)
§ 53.006 FEES TO BE CHARGED FOR AFTER HOURS CALLS.
   When any service interruption has been experienced or a dangerous condition
may occur, calls shall be made through Wayne-White Counties Electric
Cooperative. The costs incurred to repair any part of a system, on the
customer’s side of the meter, or due to faults caused by the customer’s system,
shall be borne by the electric customer, provided the repair is necessitated
under emergency conditions. No repair on the customer’s system shall be made by
Wayne-White Counties Electric Cooperative personnel except when a dangerous
condition may exist that would endanger the health and welfare of an electric
user and cannot otherwise be remedied.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.050) (Ord. 22-0125-276, passed 1-25-2022)
§ 53.007 REPAIRS.
   The user shall be responsible for all repairs on the customer’s side of the
meter loop, except for the meter itself.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.060) (Ord. 22-0125-276, passed 1-25-2022)
§ 53.008 DISCONNECTION OF SERVICE DUE TO NONPAYMENT; RECONNECTION FEE.
   If any bill is unpaid after the due date, the customer shall be considered
delinquent and service is subject to disconnection. A reconnection charge set
by the bill provider shall be paid by the delinquent customer before service is
restored.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.070) (Ord. 937, passed 5-18-1971; Ord. 1218, passed 5-24-
1983; Ord. 1251, passed - -1984; Ord. 20-1124-238, passed 11-24-2020; Ord. 22-
0125-276, passed 1-25-2022)
§ 53.009 DISCONNECTION OF SERVICE DUE TO TAMPERING WITH, ALTERING OR INJURING
METER; RECONNECTION FEE.
   If any meter is discovered to have been tampered with, altered or injured,
the meter shall be removed immediately and service shall be discontinued. A
reconnection charge of $100 shall be paid by the applicant for service before
service is restored. Tampering with, altering or injuring a meter is defined to
include wiring the meter or meter base so as to cause the reading mechanism of
the meter to be inoperable or inaccurate.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.075)
§ 53.010 INTERFERENCE.
   Uses of electric service which cause disturbance on the electric
distribution system and interference with service to other customers will not
be allowed.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.080) (Ord. 937, passed 5-18-1971; Ord. 1251, passed - -1984)
Penalty, see §
53.999

   Electric service taken under the rate schedules set forth in this chapter
shall not be resold.
(1986 Code, § 8.04.090) (Ord. 937, passed 5-18-1971; Ord. 1251, passed - -1984)
