GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 92.001 CREATION AND PLAT.
   The tract of land laid off and platted by the city, known and designated as
the Fairfield Cemetery, and recorded in Book No. 45, Page 1 of the records in
the Recorder’s office of Wayne County, Illinois, shall be held and kept as a
city cemetery, and shall hereafter be called Maple Hill Cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.02.010) (Ord. 3, passed 8-14-1922)
§ 92.002 REVISED PLAT.
   (A)   The roadways, walkways and burial lots of the addition to the Maple
Hill Cemetery in the city, as evidenced by a certain plat of record in Book A
of Page 199, in the office of the Recorder of Deeds, Wayne County, Illinois,
be, and they are hereby altered to conform as to number of lots, location and
width of lots, and location and width of walkways and roadways, in accordance
with a revised plat of the addition to the Maple Hill Cemetery, a copy of the
plat being kept in the office of the City Clerk, and made a part hereof by
reference.
   (B)   The City Clerk is hereby directed to cause to be recorded a copy of
the revised plat in the office of the Recorder of Deeds in and for the county.
(1986 Code, § 4.02.020) (Ord. 485-A, passed 12-17-1940)
§ 92.003 ADDITIONS TO MAPLE HILL CEMETERY; PLATS.
   The addition to Maple Hill Cemetery acquired in October, 1943 by
condemnation shall be called “East Addition to Maple Hill Cemetery” and it and
all other tracts of land hereafter acquired for cemetery purposes shall be
divided into lots and a map or plat shall be made thereof and one copy shall be
kept in the office of the City Clerk and made a part hereof and another copy
shall be kept in the office of the sexton of the cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.02.030) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.004 VALIDITY.
   If any section or part of this chapter is declared illegal or void, all
other parts shall remain in full force and effect.
(1986 Code, § 4.02.040) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
GRANTING THE RIGHT TO BURY
§ 92.015 AUTHORITY TO GRANT RIGHT TO BURY.
   The city may grant to individuals, or to churches, lodges or other
organizations the right to bury upon certain designated lots in the cemetery.
The grant shall be executed by the City Clerk. The right to bury so granted and
the instrument granting the right shall be subject to all the terms, rules and
regulations and charges of this chapter and any amendments hereafter adopted.
The right to bury shall not be transferable, except the right may be released
to the city. The records of the office of the City Clerk shall be conclusive
evidence as to the ownership of the right to bury upon any lot.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.010) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.016 INTERMENT PERMITTED BY GRANT ONLY; RECEIVER OF FEES DESIGNATED.
   No interment shall be made in the cemetery unless the grant or contract for
grant to the premises or lots in which the interment is so made shall first be
obtained from or issued by the City Clerk and in conformity with this chapter,
and no person or persons except as therein provided shall take, receive or
collect any fees or sums of money in connection with issuance of grant,
interment or use of any lot and premises in the cemetery, except as authorized
hereby.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.020) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.017 RECORD OF GRANTS.
   The City Clerk shall keep a record of all grants made, all contracts for
grants, the name of each grantee and the date of each, and shall keep a
permanent record at all times showing who are the grantees of all lots sold in
the cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.030) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.018 FORM OF CONVEYANCE.
   (A)   The form of conveyance may be in the following form:
Know All Men By These Presents, that the City of Fairfield, by                         , Mayor, and                         , City Clerk, party of
the first part, for and in consideration of the sum of        dollars, doth hereby grant, bargain and sell to                         , of the County
of                         , and State of                         , the following described lot or parcel of land, situated in the Maple Hill
Cemetery, and described as follows, to-wit:                                                                           to have and to hold the same to
the only proper use and benefit of the party of the second part,                          heirs and assigns forever, for burial purposes only, and
subject to the control of the City Council.
                           Dated this                          day of                          A.D. 20       .
                                          CITY OF FAIRFIELD
                                             By                          (Seal)
                                                (Mayor)
                                                                              (Seal)
                                                (City Clerk)
 
   (B)   This is not the conveyance shown in Ordinance 603, but the form now
used by City Clerk.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.040) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.019 APPLICATION FOR RIGHT TO BURY.
   Applications for the purchase of the right to bury in any lot shall be made
to the city sexton, and when the lot shall have been selected by the applicant,
the sexton shall issue to the applicant a certificate addressed to the City
Clerk over his or her signature stating that the lot is unsold, which the
certificate shall be presented to the City Clerk, and upon payment on the
charge the City Clerk shall issue a conveyance of the right to bury on the lot;
the certificate shall not be considered by the City Clerk unless dated within
five days of the date it is presented to him or her.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.050) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.020 INSTALLMENT CONTRACT ON PURCHASE OF LOTS; FAILURE TO MAKE PAYMENT.
   (A)   The City Clerk may enter into an installment contract with a proposed
purchaser of a grant of the right to bury upon the lot or lots upon the payment
of the price of the right, as provided by this chapter, or any amendment
thereto, by paying at least 50% down and the balance in equal monthly
installments of not more than six months, and upon the payment of the full
purchase price in the contract as provided therein the City Clerk shall issue
the grant of the right of burial as provided in §
92.018.
   (B)   No interment shall be permitted or memorial placed in or on any
property not fully paid for except by special consent of the City Clerk or
Sexton of the Cemetery in each and every case. In the event consent is given,
any and all interments or memorials placed in or on the property shall be
considered as temporary. A note shall not be considered as payment, and no
rights shall be acquired by the lot purchaser of the interment or interments
until the property is fully paid for in cash, including principal and interest.
In case the purchaser of the property shall fail to meet all payments within 30
days after the same are demanded by the city, then the city may re-enter the
property and hold the same as of its former estate. The city, thereupon, shall
be released from all obligations thereunder, and it may retain payments as may
have been made toward the purchase of the property as liquidated damages. The
city reserves the right, and shall have the right, immediately or at any time
thereafter, after due notice to next of kin, to remove to single graves, to be
chosen by the city, each of the remains then interred in the property. The
city, further, shall have the right to remove any memorial that has been placed
on the property; or the city may leave the body in part of lot and retain title
to remainder and re-sell the same.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.060) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947; Ord. 21-0126-243, passed
1-26-2021)
§ 92.021 GRANTS ISSUED TO A CHURCH, LODGE OR OTHER SOCIETY.
   Where a right of burial is granted to a church, lodge or other society,
interments shall be limited to the actual members of that organization and to
their husbands or wives, and to immediate families of members.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.070) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.022 RIGHTS OF INDIVIDUALS AND THEIR SURVIVORS.
   (A)   Whenever an interment is made in a plot that has been transferred by
grant to an individual grantee by the city and is held as a separate plot, it
shall be indivisible; and the whole of the burial plot thereby becomes
inalienable and shall be held as the family burial plot of the owner, in which
one grave, niche or crypt may be used for the owner’s interment, one for the
interment of the surviving husband or wife, if any, of the owner who by law has
a vested right of interment therein, and in those remaining, if any, the
children of the deceased owner may be interred, in the order of need, without
the consent of any person claiming any interest therein. In the event there
shall be no child surviving the deceased person, the right of interment therein
shall go to the next heirs at law of the deceased owner as specified by the
statutes of descent.
   (B)   On the decease of the proprietor of a lot, when the lot is not
specifically mentioned in his or her will, an affidavit must be filed at the
office of the City Clerk, signed by one of the heirs at law, and in the case of
minors, by their guardian. This affidavit must include a list of the names of
all heirs and a majority must also designate one of their number as the
representative, who shall be authorized to sign orders for interments in the
lot and to give all other needful directions regarding the lot. If no affidavit
shall be filed, the City Clerk may designate some one of the heirs at law so to
act until a time as the before-mentioned affidavit shall have been filed.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.080) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.023 ASSIGNMENT OR TRANSFER OF LOTS.
   No transfer or assignment by any grantee of the city of any plot, or
interest therein, shall be valid except to the city, and upon a reconveyance to
the city, the city shall be the owner of the plot as though it had never been
sold. The city may pay any price for reconveyance but not to exceed the
consideration originally paid for the plot or the proportionate part of the
consideration for any part of the plot reconveyed. However, if a grantee wishes
to trade a plot that they own within the cemetery for a plot of the same size,
the grantee may do so without incurring any additional charge or fee.
(1986 Code, § 4.04.090) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947; Ord. 22-0927-308, passed
9-27-2022)
FEES AND CHARGES
§ 92.035 COST OF CEMETERY LOTS.
   (A)   The charge for the right to bury in all two-grave lots in Maple Hill
Cemetery shall be$400 for each grave lot.
   (B)   The charge for the right to bury on each lot location on which
mausoleums may be built shall be $2,000. This cost includes lot and grave
opening.
   (C)   The charge for the right to bury in an in-ground single mausoleum
shall be $1,000 and for in-ground double mausoleum shall be $2,000. This cost
includes lot and grave opening.
   (D)   The charge for the right to bury in a single-grave lot shall be$400,
providing that single-grave lots shall be sold only in Lots 1 through 32 of the
roadside lots, commencing at the north edge of Washington Street in the
entrance and continuing in a northeasterly direction alongside of Park Road to
a line extended westerly from the north boundary line of Block O Old Part of
the cemetery, and also Lots 1 through 100 in Block O East Addition of Maple
Hill Cemetery.
   (E)   Upon application and certification of indigent economic status
satisfactory to the City Clerk, there shall be no charge for the right to bury
in the potter's field in the north fourth of the Block E, Old Part of Maple
Hill Cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.06.010) (Ord. 858, passed 3-1-1966; Ord. 1295, passed - -1987;
Ord. 1379, passed - -1992; Ord. 1571, passed - -2003; Ord. 21-0126-243, passed
1-26-2021)
§ 92.036 CHARGES FOR OPENING GRAVES AND SUPERVISING BURIALS.
   (A)   The charge for opening graves during Monday through Friday, except
city holidays, shall be $400.
   (B)   The charge for opening graves during Saturday and city holidays shall
be $600. A funeral service may not commence later than noon on Saturdays. If
the burial is before noon on the next business day following a weekend or a
city holiday, the charge shall be $600.
   (C)   The charge for burial of ashes shall be the same as for opening
graves.
   (D)   The charge for burial of cremation remains inside a headstone shall be
$100.
   (E)   The charge for supervising the placement of an above ground or in-
ground mausoleum, payable at the time of setting the foundation, shall be $100.
   (F)   The charge for supervising the setting of foundations for each marker
base, payable at the time of setting the foundation, shall be $20 per marker
base.
   (G)   The charge for the cemetery sexton or designated employees of the city
to oversee and supervise a disinterment shall be $300. The disinterment fee is
for bringing the casket/vault to the surface and does not include
transportation to a new location or re-interment. The cemetery sexton, or
designated employee of the city shall only oversee and supervise the
disinterment which must be performed by a private contractor, and only those
private contractors approved by the cemetery sexton. Any and all disinterments
must be scheduled at a time approved by the cemetery sexton. The city shall not
be liable or responsible for any damage to vaults or caskets which may occur in
the process of disinterment and re-interment, nor will the city be responsible
for or liable for any or all other costs or damages which are associated with
any disinterment or reinterment.
   (H)   Disinterment or reinterment in Maple Hill Cemetery on Saturday, Sunday
or city holidays shall be done at the discretion of the cemetery sexton.
   (I)   The city and employees of the city will not perform any disinterment
from and after the passage of this section.
   (J)   There shall be no fee under §
92.036 for all veterans. The term VETERAN, for the purpose of this section,
shall be the same as the definition under 38 U.S.C. § 101(2) which is as
follows: the term VETERAN means a person who served in the active military,
naval, or air service, and who was discharged or released there from under
conditions other than dishonorable.
(1986 Code, § 4.06.020) (Ord. 1379, passed - -1992; Ord. 1571, passed - -2003;
Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009; Ord. 15-1110-100, passed 11-10-2015; Ord.
21-0126-243, passed 1-26-2021; Ord. 24-0227- 359, passed 2-27-2024)
§ 92.037 DEPOSITION OF RECEIPTS FROM SALES AND SERVICES.
   All receipts and moneys accruing from sales and services shall be deposited
to the Cemetery Fund.
(1986 Code, § 4.06.030) (Ord. 1379, passed - -1992; Ord. 1411, passed - -1993)
§ 92.038 COSTS AND RULES FOR PURCHASE AND USE OF COLUMBARIUM NICHES.
   (A)   The niches shall sell for $500 each. The total cost must be paid prior
to any niche opening.
   (B)   An additional $100 will be charged for any niche which is opened on
weekends, holidays or after 4:00 p.m.
   (C)   All niche openings will be scheduled at the sole discretion of the
cemetery sexton, and inclement weather may delay each opening at the discretion
of the cemetery sexton.
   (D)   If a niche, which has been unused, with a door that has been etched,
is sold back to the city, the price of a new door will be deducted from the
refund received from the city. The niches will be sold in the order established
by the cemetery sexton, and shall be sold so that the horizontal rows of niches
will be sold in sequence; however, Niches 1 through 6 inclusive on the east and
west sides of Columbarium #2 may be sold out of sequential order.
   (E)   The only decorations on the columbarium may be made by the purchaser
of each niche; however, the decorations must be on the door of the niche, and
must be etched into the door. Only the ashes from the cremation of one person
may be stored in each niche.
   (F)   No animal or pet ashes, or any other object of any type, may be stored
in a niche.
   (G)   Niches cannot be re-opened except to transfer the contents to a new
site.
   (H)   All lettering etched in the doors must be in “condensed Roman”
letters.
   (I)   The concrete foundation of the columbarium is owned by the city and no
personal property or decorations of any type will be allowed on the foundation.
   (J)   Any flowers, decorations or personal property brought to the cemetery,
at the time of the niche opening and burial ceremony, shall be placed on the
ground and will be removed by cemetery personnel within three days.
   (K)   The CINERARY URNS are containers for the ashes and may not exceed 12
inches high by 12 inches wide by 16 inches deep.
   (L)   If the owner of any niche causes any damage or takes any action which
is prohibited by these rules, the owner shall be responsible for and liable for
the cost to repair or replace the damage. There shall be no objects, personal
property, flowers or other decorations of any type allowed on the top of the
columbarium. There shall also be no adhesive vases or any other items that may
be attached to the niche doors using adhesive or any other method.
   (M)   Niches are to be opened and closed by cemetery personnel only.
   (N)   Cemetery personnel must have at least 24 hours’ advance notice prior
to any niche opening or burial ceremony involving the columbarium.
   (O)   The cost for a niche allows the purchaser the right to use the niche
for burial purposes only and the niche will always remain the property of the
city.
   (P)   After the purchaser of a niche pays the required costs, the City Clerk
will issue to the purchaser a permit for the use of a niche with a specific
number in the columbarium which is owned by the city. This permit shall entitle
the purchaser to perpetual and unlimited use of the niche purchased, subject to
all rules and regulations imposed by the city.
(Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009)
INTERMENTS, DISINTERMENTS AND REMOVALS
§ 92.050 SUBJECT TO CITY, COUNTY AND STATE LAWS.
   Besides being subject to these rules and regulations, all interments,
disinterments and removals are made subject to the orders and laws of the
properly constituted authorities of the city, county and state.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.010)
§ 92.051 SUBJECT TO ORDINANCES.
   All interments, disinterments and removals must be made at the time and in
the manner and subject to the charges as fixed by ordinances.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.020)
§ 92.052 SUNDAYS AND HOLIDAYS; FEES AND CHARGES.
   Interments, disinterments and removals on Sundays are hereby prohibited.
Interment, disinterments and removals on holidays are regarded with disfavor;
when necessary, these services are subject to special additional charges. An
additional charge shall be made when any service necessitates payment for
overtime labor. All charges shall be fixed by the sexton, if not specifically
fixed by ordinance.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.030) (Ord. 1379, passed - -1992; Ord. 24-0227-359, passed 2-
27-2024)
CEMETERY RULES AND REGULATIONS
§ 92.065 NOTICE TO BE GIVEN TO SEXTON BEFORE INTERMENT OR DISINTERMENT.
   The right is reserved to insist upon at least 24 hours’ notice to the sexton
prior to any interment, and at least one week’s notice prior to any
disinterment or removal.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.040)
§ 92.066 SEXTON’S AUTHORITY WHEN LOCATION OF INTERMENT SPACE IN A LOT IS
UNOBTAINABLE OR INDEFINITE OR INTERMENT SPACE CANNOT BE OPENED WHEN SPECIFIED.
   When instructions regarding the location of an interment space in a lot
cannot be obtained, or are indefinite, or when, for any reason, the interment
space cannot be opened when specified, the sexton may, in his or her
discretion, open it in a location in the lot as he or she deems best and
proper, so as not to delay the funeral; neither the sexton nor the city shall
be liable in damages for any error so made.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.050)
§ 92.067 NUMBER OF BURIALS ALLOWED IN GRAVE, VAULT, CRYPT, OR NICHE; EXCEPTION.
   Not more than one body and one cremation remains or no more than three
cremation remains shall be interred in one grave, vault, or crypt, except by
written consent of the sexton and provided proper identification is made of the
interment or interments on one regulation crypt, memorial or marker. Only one
cremation remains shall be placed in a niche.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.060) (Ord. 21-0126-243, passed 1-26-2021) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.068 OPENING A CASKET OR TOUCHING A BODY WITHIN CONFINES OF CEMETERY.
   Once a casket containing a body is within the confines of the cemetery, no
funeral director, or his or her embalmer, assistant, employee or agent, shall
be permitted to open the casket or to touch the body without the consent of the
legal representatives of the deceased and the sexton, or without a court order.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.070)
§ 92.069 REMAINS OF HUMAN BEING ONLY PERMITTED WITHIN CEMETERY.
   No interment of any body, or the cremated remains of any body, other than
that of a human being, shall be permitted in the cemeteries.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.080) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.070 REMOVAL OF BODY OR REMAINS FORBIDDEN; WHEN.
   Removal, by the heirs, of a body or cremated remains so that the plot may be
sold for profit to themselves, or removal contrary to the express or implied
wish of the original plot owner, is repugnant to the ordinary sense of decency
and is absolutely forbidden.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.090) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.071 REMOVAL OF BODY OR REMAINS FROM ORIGINAL PLOT TO ANOTHER PLOT
PERMITTED; WHEN.
   A body, or cremated remains, may be removed from its original plot to
another plot in the cemetery, where there has been an exchange or purchase for
that purpose approved by the sexton or Chairperson of Cemetery Committee.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.100)
§ 92.072 CHARGES FOR CEMETERY SERVICES PAYABLE; WHEN.
   The charges for the cemetery services must be paid at the time of the
issuance of the order of interment, disinterment or removal.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.110)
§ 92.073 CITY MAY REFUSE SERVICE ON ANY LOT UNTIL ARRANGEMENTS FOR PAYMENT HAVE
BEEN MADE.
   The city reserves the right to refuse to do, or allow to be done, work of
any character, including interments in or upon any lot, until arrangements have
been made for payment of any and all indebtedness due the city for work
performed in or upon the lot.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.120)
§ 92.074 NUMBERING OF GRAVES.
   All graves in the cemetery shall be numbered from south to north on each lot
or half lot.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.130)
§ 92.075 PLACEMENT OF GRAVES WITHIN LOTS.
   (A)   The south line of Grave Number One on each lot shall be one foot from
the south line of the lot.
   (B)   The north line of Grave Number Four on each lot and of Grave Number
Two on the north half of each lot shall be one foot from the north line of the
lot.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.140) (Ord. 1571, passed - -2003)
§ 92.076 SINGLE GRAVES.
   Single graves shall be sold only in Lots 1 through 32 of the roadside lots
commencing at the north edge of Washington Street entrance and continuing in a
northeasterly direction alongside of Park Road to a line extended westerly from
the north boundary line of Block O, old part of Maple Hill Cemetery, and also
Lots 1 through 100 in Block O, east addition to Maple Hill Cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.150) (Ord. 1379, passed - -1992)
§ 92.077 CARE OF CEMETERY.
   All openings and closings of graves, and all interments, shall be made only
by the cemetery personnel. Cemetery personnel shall oversee and supervise any
disinterment or removal and will be performed by a private contractor that has
been approved by the cemetery sexton.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.160) (Ord. 1571, passed - -2003; Ord. 21-0126-243, passed 1-
26-2021)
§ 92.078 IMPROVEMENTS OR ALTERATIONS MADE WITHOUT WRITTEN CONSENT.
   Should any improvements or alterations be made without written consent of
the sexton, he or she shall have the right to remove, alter or change the
improvements or alterations at the expense of the plot owner.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.170)
§ 92.079 DETRIMENTAL, UNSIGHTLY OR INCONVENIENT TREES OR SHRUBS; AUTHORITY OF
SEXTON.
   No bushes, shrubs or trees shall be planted on any lot.
(Ord. 14-1222-87, passed 12-22-2014)
§ 92.080 PLACEMENT OF CERTAIN ITEMS ON PLOTS PROHIBITED.
   No flowers or decorations on, or in the ground, shall be allowed year round,
except one shepherd hook per grave lot. The shepherd hook can only be placed at
the north or south end of the monument or marker. The only exception for
flowers or decorations will be for the following holidays: Memorial Day;
Veterans’ Day; Labor Day; Easter; and Christmas. Decorations for Memorial Day,
Veterans’ Day, Labor Day, and Easter will be discarded by cemetery personnel
one week after the holidays. Christmas decorations and grave blankets will be
discarded by cemetery personnel by March 1 annually.
(Ord. 14-1222-87, passed 12-22-2014)
§ 92.081 DISPLAY OF AMERICAN FLAG.
   As a special mark of respect to those who have so served our country, the
American flag may be displayed on the graves of those persons who have
honorably served in the armed forces of the United States of America.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.200)
§ 92.082 BURIAL IN VETERANS’ CEMETERY.
   Before a veteran may be buried in the Veterans’ Cemetery, he or she must
have fulfilled all requirements as set forth by the Veterans’ Cemetery
Committee (a committee of the Veterans of Foreign Wars organization). If these
requirements have not been fulfilled, the burial may be denied by the cemetery
sexton or Chairperson of the Cemetery Committee of the City Council.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.210)
§ 92.083 PLACEMENT OF MAUSOLEUMS ON CERTAIN PLOTS ONLY.
   Mausoleums shall be placed only on plots set aside for that purpose, as
shown on the maps of the cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.220)
§ 92.084 CERTAIN AREAS PERMITTED FOR USE OF PEOPLE VISITING CEMETERY GROUNDS.
   Persons within the cemetery grounds shall use only the avenues, walks,
alleys and roads.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.230) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.085 PERSONS INJURED WITHIN CEMETERY; CITY LIABILITY.
   Any person injured in any manner in the cemetery shall in no way hold the
city liable for any injuries sustained.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.240) (Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009)
§ 92.086 REFRESHMENTS AND LUNCHES PROHIBITED.
   No persons shall be permitted to have refreshments or lunches within the
cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.250) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.087 LOITERING PROHIBITED.
   Loitering shall not be permitted on any of the grounds, graves or monuments
in the cemetery, or in any of the buildings.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.260) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.088 LITTERING PROHIBITED.
   Receptacles for waste material shall be located at convenient places. The
throwing of rubbish on the drives and paths or on any part of the grounds or in
the buildings is prohibited.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.270) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.089 OPERATION OF AUTOMOBILES.
   (A)   Automobiles shall not be driven through the grounds at a greater speed
than 15 mph, and must always be kept on the right-hand side of the cemetery
roadway, unless otherwise directed by the sexton, or his or her assistants.
Automobiles are not allowed to park or to come to a full stop in front of an
open grave unless the automobiles are in attendance at the funeral. Automobiles
must not turn in the driveways or avenues but must proceed to the next
intersection before changing direction.
   (B)   Motor cars and vehicles must be kept under complete control at all
times. When meeting a funeral procession, they must stop until the procession
passes. They must not pass a funeral procession going in the same direction.
Motor cars must not be left with the engine running and the emergency brake
must be set when the driver is not in his or her seat. Mufflers must not be
open nor the horn sounded within the cemetery.
   (C)   No motor car, vehicle or animal shall be driven across or upon any
grave, lot or lawn nor parked or left thereon. It is prohibited to park or
leave any motor car or vehicle on any road or driveway within the cemetery at a
location or in a position as to prevent any other car or vehicle from passing
the same, and if so parked or left, the motor car or vehicle will be removed
with the towing expense charged to the owner of the car.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.280) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.090 USE AS THOROUGHFARE PROHIBITED; COMMERCIAL OR BUSINESS VEHICLES
PROHIBITED WITHOUT SEXTON’S PERMISSION.
   The use of the cemetery as a thoroughfare is prohibited, and commercial or
business vehicles are permitted to enter only by permission from the sexton.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.290) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.091 DOGS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION.
   Dogs shall not be allowed on the cemetery grounds or in any of the
buildings, except on leash. Any dog waste must be picked up and discarded by
the owner of the dog or the person who is in charge of the dog when the dog is
in the cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.300) (Ord. 14-1222-87, passed 12-22-2014) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.092 PERSONS ENGAGED IN ERECTING MONUMENTS OR OTHER STRUCTURES.
   Persons engaged in erecting monuments or other structures are prohibited
from attaching ropes to monuments, trees and shrubs, or from scattering their
material over adjoining lots, or from blocking avenues or pathways, or from
leaving their material on the grounds longer than is absolutely necessary. They
must do as little injury to the grass, trees and shrubs as possible, and must
remove all debris and restore the ground and sod to its original condition.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.310)
§ 92.093 MATERIAL, MACHINERY OR OTHER THINGS FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF VAULTS,
MAUSOLEUMS, MONUMENTS OR OTHER STRUCTURES; REGULATIONS.
   No material, machinery or other thing for the construction of vaults,
mausoleums, monuments or other structures or monuments themselves, may be
brought into the cemetery until required for immediate use; nor, under any
circumstances, when a funeral is in progress; nor between Saturday noon and
Monday morning; nor on a holiday; and no work shall be done during the time;
nor shall the material be placed on lots adjoining the one on which a structure
is to be erected, without special permission from the sexton.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.320)
§ 92.094 PROGRESS OF WORK.
   Work shall proceed promptly and continuously until the erection of the
memorial is completed.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.330)
§ 92.095 SOLICITING MEMORIAL BUSINESS; PROHIBITED.
   Approaching the bereaved and soliciting memorial business within the
cemetery is not permitted.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.340) (Ord. 604, passed 8-19-1947) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.096 INJURING, DEFACING, REMOVING OR DESTROYING CERTAIN ARTICLES
PROHIBITED; CUTTING, BREAKING, REMOVING OR INJURING CERTAIN ARTICLES BY CONSENT
OF SEXTON.
   No person shall injure, deface, remove or destroy any vault, tomb, monument,
gravestone or other memorial, or any fence or enclosure about the cemeteries,
or shall cut, break, remove or injure any tree, shrub or plant within any
cemetery without the consent of the sexton.
(1986 Code, § 4.08.350) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.097 CEMETERY EQUIPMENT.
   All cemetery equipment, including, but not limited to, mowers, trucks,
tractors and backhoes, will have the right-of-way at all times, and all
visitors must yield to the cemetery equipment.
(Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009)
§ 92.098 DIGGING OF GRAVES.
   Graves may only be dug by city employees who are cemetery personnel.
(Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009)
§ 92.099 PERSONAL PROPERTY IN GRAVES.
   The cemetery sexton and other cemetery personnel will have the sole
discretion as to what objects or personal property, other than the burial
casket and vault, which may be put in a grave.
(Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009)
§ 92.100 VAULT OR CONCRETE BOX.
   All caskets must be placed in a vault or, at a minimum, in a concrete box,
unless the body has been cremated.
(Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009)
§ 92.101 CITY NOT LIABLE.
   The city and cemetery personnel are not liable for injuries to persons
walking, jogging, bicycling or in any other way exercising on cemetery
property. The city and cemetery personnel will not be liable for damage to
vehicles or other personal property which may occur on cemetery property, while
they are working, mowing or weedeating.
(Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009; Ord. 21-0126-243, passed 1-26-2021)
§ 92.102 CEMETERY HOURS.
   The cemetery shall be closed to the public from 9:00 p.m. each night until
5:00 a.m. each morning. This section shall be effective after signs are posted
at the cemetery indicating that the cemetery is closed to the public from 9:00
p.m. each night until 5:00 a.m. each morning.
(Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009)
MONUMENTS AND MARKERS
§ 92.115 CENTRAL OR FAMILY MEMORIAL; NUMBER ALLOWED ON LOT; PLACEMENT.
   Only one central or family memorial shall be allowed on a lot, and that
shall be set on the east side of the plot, and the space shall be designated by
the sexton.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.010)
§ 92.116 NO MEMORIAL MAY BE ERECTED WHEN SEXTON DISAPPROVES.
   No lot owner shall erect or place, or cause to be erected or placed, on any
lot in the cemetery, any memorial in respect of which the sexton disapproves.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.020)
§ 92.117 MAXIMUM SIZE AND PLACEMENT OF MEMORIAL ALLOWED ON LOTS.
   The maximum size of a memorial to be placed upon a lot shall be as follows:
   (A)   A memorial for one-grave lot shall not exceed two feet, eight inches
in length;
   (B)   A memorial for a two-grave lot shall not exceed eight feet in length;
   (C)   A memorial for a four-grave lot shall not exceed 16 feet in length;
   (D)   The width of the base shall not exceed the depth of monument space
available on the lot, and in no case may the base extend over an occupied
grave;
   (E)   The height of a memorial, including base, shall not be more than four
feet from level of ground; and
   (F)   The east line of a memorial shall be on the east line of all lots in
Blocks A, B, C and D. In all other blocks, the west line of any memorial shall
be on the west line of lot.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.030) (Ord. 858, passed 3-1-1966)
§ 92.118 MARKERS; REQUIREMENTS; PLACEMENT IN BLOCKS A, B, C AND D.
   Markers shall be flush with the ground. All lettering on surface markers
must be cut in or incised. In Blocks A, B, C and D, the west line of markers
shall be placed on the west line of the lot and in all other blocks, the east
line of the markers shall be placed on the east line of the lot.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.040) (Ord. 757, passed 3-1-1960)
§ 92.119 CERTAIN STRUCTURES, DECORATIONS AND MATERIALS PROHIBITED; ABATEMENT BY
SEXTON.
   No coping, curbing, fencing, hedging, grave mounds, borders or enclosures of
any kind shall be allowed around any lot; and no walks of brick, cinders, tile,
stone, marble, terra-cotta, sand, cement, gravel or wood shall be allowed on
any lot. The sexton shall have the right to remove the same if so erected,
planted or placed. No glass or ceramic items will be allowed on any lot.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.050) (Ord. 14-1222-87, passed 12-22-2014) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.120 SEXTON MAY STOP WORK OF ANY NATURE.
   The sexton shall have the right to stop all work of any nature, whenever, in
his or her opinion, proper preparations have not been made; or when tools and
machinery are insufficient or defective; or when work is being executed in a
manner as to threaten life or property; or when any reasonable request on the
part of the sexton is disregarded; or when work is not being executed according
to specifications; or when any person employed on the work violates any rule of
the cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.060)
§ 92.121 MAUSOLEUMS OR TOMBS; PLACEMENT; MATERIALS.
   Mausoleums or tombs, either wholly or partially above ground, shall be
constructed only in lots so designated by the city and shall be built of first-
grade material similar in all respects to stone used in other memorials within
the cemetery.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.070)
§ 92.122 PRIVATE MAUSOLEUMS; REGULATIONS.
   When an interment is made in a private mausoleum, the casket must be metal-
lined and the crypt shall be hermetically sealed.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.080)
§ 92.123 CITY TO REGULATE ALL WORK; ASSUMES RESPONSIBILITY FOR CONSTRUCTION OF
FOUNDATIONS.
   As a guarantee of good work and as protection to all lot owners, the city
reserves the right to excavate for and build all foundations, supervise the
setting of all markers and memorials, and to regulate all work done in the
cemetery. The city shall assume responsibility for the proper construction of
the foundation. The charge therefor shall be $5 per cubic foot, except in the
Veterans’ Cemetery which the fee shall be in accordance with amount paid by
Veterans Administration.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.090) (Ord. 878, passed 8-1-1967)
§ 92.124 UNDESIRABLE MEMORIAL, MAUSOLEUM OR TOMB; ABATEMENT.
   Should any memorial, mausoleum or tomb become unsightly, dilapidated or a
menace to visitors, the city shall have the right either to correct the
condition or to remove the same, with prior notification to next of kin when
possible, at the expense of the lot owner.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.150) (Ord. 603, passed 8-19-1947)
§ 92.125 MARKER REQUIREMENTS IN VETERAN’S CEMETERY.
   Only granite markers will be allowed in the veteran’s cemetery section.
(Ord. 21-0126-243, passed 1-26-2021)
FOUNDATIONS
§ 92.130 BUILDING OF FOUNDATION; RESTRICTED BY WEATHER.
   No foundations will be built when the weather is so that injury from frost
cannot be prevented. No heavy stone work may be set in inclement weather or
until the cement in the foundation shall have had time to harden thoroughly.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.100) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.131 FOUNDATIONS; SIZE.
   (A)   Foundations will be made to extend at least five inches beyond both
sides of the bottom base, or first masonry course above the ground, but the
sexton shall have the right to require a larger foundation when, in his or her
opinion, the weight of the structure requires it.
   (B)   Foundation orders must specify the exact size of the bottom base or
first masonry course above ground.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.110)
§ 92.132 FOUNDATIONS; DEPTH; FINISH.
   Foundations shall be built to a depth of at least three feet and deeper when
in the opinion of the sexton it is required, and shall be finished two inches
below the surface of the ground where lowest.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.120)
§ 92.133 FOUNDATION AND SETTING CHARGES; WHEN PAYABLE.
   Foundation and setting charges shall be payable in advance.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.130)
§ 92.134 FINISHING FOUNDATION; NOTICE TO SEXTON.
   The sexton shall have ten days’ notice before he or she is required to
finish any foundation.
(1986 Code, § 4.10.140)
§ 92.135 DAMAGE TO FOUNDATIONS.
   Concrete foundations and marble or granite slabs are not considered part of
the monument, and cemetery personnel and the city are not liable for damage
from mowers, grave digging or other cemetery maintenance.
(Ord. 09-1027-15, passed 10-27-2009)
§ 92.999 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter
shall be fined not less than $75 nor more than $750 for each offense; and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 20-0512-211, passed 5-12-2020)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 93.01 ESTABLISHED.
   The city owns and operates an airport known as Fairfield Municipal Airport.
(1986 Code, § 12.02.010)
§ 93.02 CONSENT TO ORDINANCES.
   Any person making use of the area belonging to the airport, or found
thereon, shall be held to have consented to all ordinances of a general nature
as being applicable to his or her conduct in or over the airport, just as they
are applicable to persons within the city limits.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.010)
§ 93.03 JURISDICTION OF AIRPORT AUTHORITY.
   The City Council shall have jurisdiction over the airport and persons in, on
or over it.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.020)
§ 93.04 GENERAL ORDINANCES.
   All general ordinances of the city pertaining to the conduct of persons
shall be in full force and effect in the airport.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.030)
§ 93.05 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The City Council may promulgate those rules and regulations as necessary to
ensure the orderly conduct of the affairs of the airport. These rules and
regulations, when adopted, shall be printed and copies of the rules and
regulations put in prominent places throughout the airport. A copy of the
regulations shall be given to all persons leasing any real property within the
airport at the time the lease is entered into.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.040)
§ 93.06 USE OF CAR.
   (A)   The city may provide the use of an automobile to anyone arriving at
the airport by airplane requiring transportation to the city, but no other
destination, and for a period of two hours only at any particular time.
   (B)   The automobile will be maintained by the city and no fee charged for
its use.
   (C)   When a donation for the service is given, the donation shall be
applied to the Airport Fund.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.050)
§ 93.07 COMPLIANCE TO FEDERAL AVIATION REGULATIONS.
   Anyone landing, taking off or flying over the Fairfield Municipal Airport
shall comply with all rules and regulations of the Federal Aviation
Administration.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.060)
§ 93.08 AIRPLANES PARKED ON FIELD.
   (A)   Anyone parking an airplane on the airport field shall do so in an area
provided for that purpose.
   (B)   The airplane shall be tied down in a manner so that it shall be safe
from damages, theft and harm to anyone or anything within the airport.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.070) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.09 RESTRICTED AREAS.
   (A)   No one shall be allowed in the hangars except persons renting space in
the hangars or authorized personnel.
   (B)   No one shall be allowed in the area west of the fence separating
automobile parking and aircraft parking or on the runways or taxiways, except
authorized personnel, pilots, passengers of incoming and outgoing airplanes,
and persons maintaining or storing airplanes.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.080) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.10 DAMAGE TO AIRCRAFT.
   Any person damaging, intentionally or unintentionally, an airplane, stored
or parked within the municipal airport, or anything pertaining thereto, shall
be held responsible for the damages and will be required to make restitution.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.090) Penalty, see §
93.99
BUILDINGS AND REAL ESTATE
§ 93.25 MAINTENANCE.
   The airport buildings and landing field shall be maintained by the city,
unless otherwise specified by the City Council.
(1986 Code, § 12.06.010)
§ 93.26 DAMAGE TO AIRPORT.
   Any person damaging, intentionally or unintentionally, the airport
buildings, landing field or anything pertaining thereto, shall be held
responsible for the damages and will be required to make restitution.
(1986 Code, § 12.06.020) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.27 STORAGE SPACE IN HANGAR; FEES.
   (A)   (1)   Anyone may rent an airplane hangar who owns or co-owns an
airworthy aircraft providing space is available. If the aircraft which is
stored in the rented hangar is sold, the lessee or lessees of the hangar will
have six months to purchase another airworthy aircraft to be stored in the
rented hangar. In the even an airworthy aircraft is not stored in a rented
hangar within six months after the sale of the stored aircraft, the lessee of
the hangar space shall lose that space, and it will be leased to the first
person or persons on the waiting list who have an airworthy aircraft for
storage in the hangar. Hangar space may not be subleased.
      (2)   The hangar rent fees are hereby established as follows:
         (a)   Hangars 1 and 2: $110/month.
         (b)   Hangars 3, 4, 5, and 6: $100/month.
         (c)   Hangars 8, 9, 11, 12, and 13: $125/month.
         (d)   End storage units - 7 and 10: $62.50/month.
         (e)   Hangars 8, 9, 11, 12, and 13 and end storage units 7 and 10 are
in the hangar building currently under construction.
   (B)   Anyone may tie down his or her airplanes at the Fairfield Municipal
Airport, provided space is available. He or she must pay a fee of $5 per 24-
hour period.
   (C)   The single stand alone hangar will no longer be leased to airplane
owners and the City of Fairfield will use this building for equipment storage
and maintenance operations necessary for the maintenance and operation of the
Fairfield Municipal Airport.
(1986 Code, § 12.06.030) (Ord. 1457, passed - -1996; Ord. 14-0128-67, passed 1-
28-2014)
§ 93.28 REAL ESTATE LEASED FOR FARMING PURPOSES; OIL AND GAS OPERATIONS AND
OTHER BUSINESSES.
   The City Council may lease airport real estate for farming, oil and gas
operations and other business purposes when in its opinion it is advisable to
do so and in compliance with the state and federal regulations. When a lease is
permitted all parties involved shall reach an agreement, which shall include
the amount of the fee to be charged. The fee shall be paid at the time
stipulated by the agreement and paid to the City Collector and applied to the
Airport Fund.
(1986 Code, § 12.06.040) (Ord. 1457, passed - -1996)
BUSINESS LICENSES
§ 93.40 BUSINESS LICENSES.
   (A)   Any person conducting a business for which a license would be required
if it were located within the city shall secure a license and pay the fee
required.
   (B)   The City Clerk, or person authorized to issue the license, may
designate a deputy for purpose of issuing the license and receiving a fee
therefor.
(1986 Code, § 12.08.010)

(1986 Code, § 12.08.020)
§ 93.42 CONDUCTING AN EXTENDED BUSINESS; FEE REQUIRED.
   When someone wishes to conduct an extended business at the airport, he or
she must receive permission from the City Council, consent to the provisions of
this subchapter and pay a fee to the City Collector and the fee shall be
applied to the Airport Fund.
(1986 Code, § 12.08.030)
AIRCRAFT
§ 93.55 OPERATING AIRCRAFT OVER CITY; HEIGHT ABOVE GROUND LEVEL.
   No person shall operate any aircraft over any part of the city at a height
of less than 1,000 feet above ground level of the city, except while landing
the aircraft or taking off from an airfield, when in the landing and taking off
it is necessary for the aircraft to pass over the city.
(1986 Code, § 14.02.010) (Ord. 592, passed 11-19-1946) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.56 OPERATING EMERGENCY HELICOPTER SERVICE.
   Notwithstanding anything in this subchapter to the contrary, this subchapter
shall not prohibit any helicopter from landing or taking off from the heliport
at the Fairfield Memorial Hospital, nor any helicopter from landing or taking
off at any other location within the city limits when necessary for emergency
purposes.
(1986 Code, § 14.02.015) (Ord. 1328, passed - -1988)
§ 93.57 ACROBATICS.
   No person operating an aircraft over the city shall perform any acrobatics
over any part of the city.
(1986 Code, § 14.02.020) (Ord. 592, passed 11-19-1946) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.58 NOISE.
   No person operating any aircraft over the city shall make any unnecessary
noise.
(1986 Code, § 14.02.030) (Ord. 592, passed 11-19-1946) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter, for which no other
penalty is provided, shall be subject to the penalty provisions of §
10.99.
   (B)   Any person violating any provision of §§
93.02 through
93.10, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $500.
(1986 Code, § 12.04.100)
   (C)   Any person violating §§
93.55,
93.57 or
93.58 shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $100.
(1986 Code, § 14.02.040)
(Ord. 592, passed 11-19-1946)

OPEN BURNING
§ 94.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DOMICILE WASTE. Any refuse generated on a single-family domiciliary property
as a result of domiciliary activities. The term includes landscape waste, but
excludes garbage and trade waste.
   FIRE PIT APPARATUS. A structure that is no larger than four feet in
diameter, with a maximum depth of 12 inches below ground level, and a height
not exceeding two feet from ground level; and that is surrounded by masonry
stone (which would be bricks, concrete blocks or rock).
   GARBAGE. Refuse resulting from the handling, processing, preparation,
cooling and consumption of food or food products.
   LANDSCAPE WASTE.  Any vegetable or plant refuse, except garbage. The term
includes stumps, brush, weeds, leaves, grass, shrubbery, yard trimmings and
crop residues.
   OPEN BURNING. The combustion of any matter in a way that the products of the
combustion are emitted to the open air without originating in or passing
through equipment for which a permit could be issued under § 9(b) of the
Environmental Protection Act, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 111-1/2, § 1009(b).
   PORTABLE FIREPLACE. A commercially prefabricated appliance such as a clay
chimenea or a metal outdoor fireplace. All parts for such appliance, including,
but not limited to, the screen, lid, and grate must be used according to the
manufacturer's direction.
   RECREATIONAL FIRE. A fire set for cooking, enjoyment, or ceremonial
purposes.
   REFUSE. Any discarded matter; or any matter which is to be reduced in
volume, or otherwise changed in chemical or physical properties, in order to
facilitate its discard, removal or disposal.
   RESTRICTED AREAS. The area within the boundaries of the city, plus a zone
extending one mile beyond the boundaries of the city.
   TRADE WASTE.  Any refuse resulting from the prosecution of any trade,
business, industry, commercial venture, utility or service activity, and any
government or institutional activity, whether or not for profit. The term
includes landscape waste but excludes agricultural waste. The term excludes
dimensional lumber, plywood and particle board.
(1986 Code, § 14.04.010) (Ord. 954, passed 3-7-1972; Ord. 23-1024-346, passed
10-24-2023)
§ 94.002 OPEN BURNING UNLAWFUL; EXCEPTION.
   (A)   No person shall cause or allow open burning in the restricted area
except as hereinafter provided.
   (B)   No person shall cause or allow the burning of any refuse in any
chamber or apparatus unless the chamber or apparatus is designed for the
purpose of disposing of the class of refuse being burned.
   (C)    No person shall light or maintain any fire in the restricted area,
which is so close to any building or structure, or any flammable material
(other than that to be burned), so as to cause a fire hazard.
   (D)    No burn barrels are permitted to be used for any open burning within
the restricted area, except that a barrel may be used for firefighter training
purposes.
   (E)   All open burning fires must be extinguished at the request of any law
enforcement official, any firefighter employed with the City of Fairfield Fire
Department or any city official or their designee.
   (F)   Open burning shall be allowed only if atmospheric conditions will
readily dissipate contaminants.
   (G)   Open burning is not allowed if it creates a visibility hazard on
roadways, railroad tracks or
air fields.
   (H)   The setting of fires to combat or limit existing fires when reasonably
necessary in the judgment of the responsible government officials shall not
constitute a violation of this subchapter.
   (I)   Open burning for which a permit has been obtained from the Pollution
Control Board and is valid on the date of the burning shall not constitute a
violation of this subchapter.
(1986 Code, § 14.04.020) (Ord. 954, passed 3-7-1972; Ord. 23-1024-346, passed
10-24-2023) Penalty, see §
94.999
§ 94.003 ALLOWABLE ACTIVITIES - MISCELLANEOUS.
   The following activities are not in violation of this subchapter unless they
cause air pollution as defined in the Environmental Protection Act:
   (A)   The burning of waste gases provided all flares shall be equipped with
smokeless tips or comparable devices to reduce pollution;
   (B)   Small open flames for heating tar, for welding, acetylene torches,
highway safety flares and the like.
(1986 Code, § 14.04.030) (Ord. 954, passed 3-7-1972; Ord. 23-1024-346, passed
10-24-2023)
§ 94.004 ACTIVITIES ALLOWED - LANDSCAPE WASTE.
   The following activities are not in violation of §§
94.002 and
94.003, unless they cause air pollution as defined in the Environmental
Protection Act:
   (A)   The open burning of landscape waste is only allowed on the premises on
which such landscape waste is generated.
   (B)   (1)   The burning of landscape waste only during the months of March 1
through May 15, September, October, November and December of each year in the
area outside the central business district on private property, and not on any
public street, sidewalk, alley or right-of-way, during the hours from sunrise
to sunset; and
      (2)   Any burning of landscape waste at sunset shall be immediately
extinguished by the person setting the fire.
   (C)   Before a landscape waste fire is set, the property owner or his/her
designee must have a means of extinguishing the fire available for immediate
use. Such means of extinguishment shall either be a 4-A functional fire
extinguisher or a functional garden hose with a working and functional water
spigot.
   (D)    The landscape waste fire must be attended to and monitored at all
times.
(1986 Code, § 14.04.040) (Ord. 954, passed 3-7-1972; Ord. 990, passed 10-9-
1973; Ord. 1036, passed 3-9-1976; Ord. 994, passed 3-12-1976; Ord. 23-1024-346,
passed 10-24-2023)
§ 94.005 ACTIVITIES ALLOWED - RECREATIONAL FIRE.
   A recreational fire shall be permitted within the restricted area, subject
to the conditions and limitations contained herein:
   (A)   A recreational fire may only be set and maintained in a fire pit
apparatus; or a portable fireplace.
   (B)   The recreational fire must be attended to and monitored at all times.
    (C)   Before a recreational fire is set, the property owner or his/her
designee must have a means of extinguishing the fire available for immediate
use. Such means of extinguishment shall either be a 4-A functional fire
extinguisher a functional garden hose with a working and functional water
spigot.
   (D)   The recreational fire must be extinguished on or before 11:00 p.m. No
recreational fire is permitted between the hours of 11:00 p.m. through and
including 7:00 a.m.
   (E)   Only the following material may be used for a recreational fire:
untreated, unpainted, clean, seasoned, dry wood and manufactured fire logs. No
construction materials may be used for a recreational fire. Propane and other
similar gases may be burned as long as the portable fireplace device is rated
for that type of fuel. However, a small amount of paper and/or brush may be
used to start the fire as kindling. Logs cannot be longer than 24 inches for
use for a recreational fire. All recreational fire material must be contained
within either the fire pit apparatus or the portable fireplace.
(Ord. 23-1024-346, passed 10-24-2023)
VOLATILE GAS
§ 94.020 RESTRICTIONS.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of filling
tanks, cylinders or drums with volatile gas under pressure, when the tanks,
cylinders or drums are to be moved to other locations, unless all operations
for filling the tanks, cylinders or drums are at least 100 feet from each
boundary line of the premises used for these operations.
(1986 Code, § 14.06.010) (Ord. 638, passed 1-2-1951) Penalty, see §
94.999
ABANDONED, UNATTENDED OR DISCARDED ICE BOXES, REFRIGERATORS AND THE LIKE

any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned,
unattended or discarded ice box, refrigerator or any other container of any
kind which has an air-tight door or lock which may not be released for opening
from the inside of the ice box, refrigerator or container.
(1986 Code, § 14.08.010) (Ord. 683, passed 2-16-1954) Penalty, see §

any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned,
unattended or discarded ice box, refrigerator or any other container of any
kind which has an air-tight snap lock or doors from the ice box, refrigerator
or container.
(1986 Code, § 14.08.020) (Ord. 683, passed 2-16-1954) Penalty, see §
